editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: AS IT WAS PLAYD IN THE Blacke-Friars, by the Children of her Maieſties Reuels.
AT LONDON, ¶ Printed by T. P. for Iohn Hodgets, and are to be ſould at his ſhop in Paules Church-yard. 1605.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: SLight haſtie labours in this eaſie Play,
Preſent not what you would, but what we may:
For this vouchſafe to know the onely end
Of our now ſtudie is, not to offend.
Yet thinke not, but like others raile we could,
(Beſt art Preſents, not what it can, but ſhould)
And if our pen in this ſeeme ouer ſlight,
We ſtriue not to inſtruct, but to delight,
As for ſome few, we know of purpoſe here
to taxe, and ſcowt: know firme art cannot feare
Vaine rage: onely the higheſt grace we pray
Is, you'le not taxe, vntill you iudge our Play.
Thinke and then ſpeake: tis raſhneſſe, and not wit
To ſpeake what is in paſsion, and not iudgement fit:
Sit then, with faire exſpectance, and ſuruay
Nothing but paſsionate man in his ſlight play,
Who hath this onely ill: to ſome deem'd worſt,
A modeſt diffidence, and ſelfe miſtruſt.

div.head: Fabulae argumentum.
div.p: THe difference betwixt the loue of a Curtezan, & a wife, is the full ſcope of the Play, which intermixed with the deceits of a wittie Citie Ieſter, fils vp the Comedie.

list.item: Cocledemoy A knauiſhly witty City cōpanion.

div.head: THE Dutch Curtezan.Turpe eſt diffi • de • habere nug •••
Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter 3: Pages with lightes, Malligrubb, Freeuile, Malhoureus, Tiſifen. & Caqueteur.

sp.speaker: Freeuile.
sp.p: NAy comfort my good hoaſt Sharke, my good, Mulligrubb.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Aduance thy ſnout, doe not ſuffer 〈◊〉
〈…〉 to droppe on thy ſpaniſh leather ierkin, moſt hardly honeſt Mulligrub •

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
What, cogging Cocledemoy is 〈◊〉 with a neaſt of goblets, true, what then? they will be ha •
merd out well enough, I warrant you.
Sure, ſome wiſe man would finde them out preſently.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes ſure, if we could finde out ſome wiſe man preſently▪
How was the pl • te loſt? how did it vaniſh?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
In moſt ſincere proſe thus: that man of much money, ſome witte, but leſſe honeſtie, cogging Cocledemoy, comes this night • aie into mine hoſtes Mulligrubs Tauerne heere, cals for ••• dome, the houſe being ful, Cocledemoy conſorted with hi •
〈◊〉
• r • able 〈◊〉 , his inſtrument of fornication, the baw •• Mrs.

sp.speaker: Mary Faugh,
sp.p:
are imparlarde next the ſtreete good po ••• as
their foode, black bird, Larke, woodcocke, and mine hoaſt here, comes in, cryes God bleſſe you, and departes: A blinde Harper enters, craues audience, vncaſeth, playes, the Drawer for female priuatnes ſake is nodded out, who knowing that whoſoeuer will hit the mark of profit, muſt like thoſe that ſhoot in ſtone-bowes winke with one eye, growes blind a the right ſide and departs.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: He ſhal anſwere for that winking with one eye at the laſt day.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Let him haue day till then, and he will winke with both his eyes.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Cocledemoy perceiuing none in the roome but the blind Harper, (whoſe eyes heauen had ſhut vp, from beholding wickedneſſe,) vnclaſpes a caſement to the ſtreet very patiently, pockets vp • . bowles vnnaturally, thruſtes his wench forth the window, and him ſelfe moſt prepoſterouſly with his heeles forward followes, the vnſeeing Harper playes on, bids the empty diſhes and the treacherous candles much good do them. The Drawe • returnes, but out alas, not on 〈◊〉 , but alſo the beaſt of goblets were flowne away, La • ente are raiſde.

sp.speaker: Tyſep.
sp.p: VVhich did not pierce the heauens.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The Drawers mone, mine hoaſt doth crie, the bowles are gone.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay, be not iaw falne, my moſt ſharking Mulligrub.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Tis your iuſt affliction 〈…〉 of the fellar, and repent, repent.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I am not iawfalne, but I will hang the contracting Cocledemoy, and theres an end of't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.p: Is it a right ſtone, it ſhewes well by candlelight.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So doe many thinges that are counterfeite, but I aſſure you this is a right Diamond.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.p: Might I borrow it of you, it will not a little gra • e 〈◊〉 finger in viſitation of my Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why vſe it moſt ſweet Cuqueture, vſe it.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.p: Thankes good Sir, ti's growne high night: Gentle • , reſt to you. Exit.
A torch, found wench, ſoft ſleepe, and ſanguin • dreames to you both on boy.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Let me bid you good reſt.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Not ſo truſt me, I muſt bring my friend home: I dare not giue you vp to your owne companie, I feare the warmth of wine and youth, will draw you to ſome Common houſe of laſciuious entertainement.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Moſt neceſſarie buildings Malheureus euer ſince my intention of Marriage, I doe pray for their continuance.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Lou'd Sir, your reaſon?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Marry leaſt my houſe ſhould be made one: I would haue married men loue the S • ewes, as Engliſhmen lou'd the low Countreys: wiſh war ſhould be maintain'd there, leaſt it ſhould come home to their owne dores: what, ſuffer a man to haue a hole to put his head in, though hee goe to the Pillorie for it: Youth and Appetite are aboue the Clubbe of Hercules.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: This luſt is a moſt deadly ſinne ſure.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, tis a moſt liuely ſinne ſure.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Well I am ſure, tis one of the head ſinnes.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Nay, I am ſure it is one of the middle ſinnes.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Pitie, tis growne a moſt dayly vice.

sp.p: Well, tis a ſinne.

sp.speaker: Free▪
sp.p:
I, or elſe few men would wiſh to go to Heau •…
〈…〉 to diſguiſe with my friend, I am now giving the way of 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Not to a Curtezan.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: A courteous one.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: What 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Free
sp.p: A 〈◊〉 Publican.

sp.speaker: Mal
sp.l: Deere my 〈…〉
〈◊〉 Sir, 〈…〉 the ſtrongeſt argument that ſpeakes▪
Againſt the ſoules eternitie is luſt.
Th •• Wiſemans folly, and the fools wiſd •…
But to 〈…〉
〈…〉 to beat, and 〈…〉
Nay to expe •• your health and ſtrength 〈…〉
Your precious time, and 〈…〉
Of due preferment aduantage 〈…〉
Of any worthy end to the 〈…〉
The common boſome 〈…〉

sp.p:
Alas good 〈…〉 you haue
would you haue them get their liuing by the curſe of man, the ſweat of their browes? ſo they doe, euerie man muſt follow his trade, and euerie woman her occupation: a poore decayed mechanicall mans wife, her husband is layd vp, may not ſhe lawfully be layd downe, when her husbands onely riſing, is by his wifes falling? a Captaines wife wants meanes, her Commaunder lyes in open field abroad, may not ſhe lye in ciuile armes at home. A waighting Gentlewoman that had wont to take ſay to her Lady, miſcaries, or ſo: the Court miſfortune throwes her downe, may not the Citie curteſie take her vp: doe you know no Alderman would pitie ſuch a womans caſe: why is charity growne a flint▪ or releeuing the poore and impotent an offence? You will 〈◊〉 beaſts take no money for their fleſhly entertainment: true, becauſe they are beaſts, therefore beaſtly, onely men giue to looſe, becauſe they are men, therefore manly: and indeede, where •• ſhould they beſtow their money better? In Land, the title may be crackt: In Houſes, they may bee burnt: In apparell, will weare: In wine, alas for pitie out thr • ate is but ſhort: But employ your money vpon women, and a thouſand to not 〈…〉 one of them will beſtow that on you, which ſhall • ti • le by you as long as you hue; they are no ingratefull perſons, they with giue quite for quo▪ do ye proteſt, they' • e ſweate, doe you they theyle fall doe you fall, they'le riſe, do you giue them, the 〈◊〉 Crowne, they'le giue you the french; O iustus iuſta, 〈◊〉
They fell their bodies▪ doe not better perſons fell their ſoules? nay, ſince all things haue been ſould, honor, iuſtice, aim: my, euen God himſelfe, Aye me, what baſe ignobleneſſe is it 〈◊〉 the pleaſure of a wanton bed.
Why doe men ſcrape, why heape to full heapes ioyne.
But for his Miſtreſſe, who would care for coyne▪
For this I hold to be deny'd of no man,
All thinges are made for man, and man for woman, giue 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Of ill you merite well: my hearts good friend, Leaue yet at length, at length, for know this euer Tis no ſuch ſinne to erre, but to perſeuer.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p:
Beautie is womans vertue, loue the lifes Muſique: and woman the daintines or ſecond courſe of heauens curious workmanſhip, ſince then beauty loue and woman are good, how can
the loue of womans beawty be bad and, Bonum quo communius to melius; wil't then goe with me?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Whether?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: To a houſe of ſaluation.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Saluation?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Yes 'twill make thee repent. wil't go • to the family of loue▪ I will ſhew thee my creature▪ a pretty nimble eye Dutch T ••• kin; An honeſt ſoft harted impropriation, a ſoft plūpe, round chee •• froe, that has beauty inough, for her vertue, vertue enough for a woman, and woman enough for any reaſonable man in my knowledge: wil't paſſe a long with me?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: What to a Brothell, to behold an impudent 〈◊〉 on •• not ſhall here the whole 〈◊〉 to ſee her: the moſt odious ſpectacle the earth can preſent, is an modeſt vulger woman.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Good ſtill: my braine ſhall keep't: you muſt goe as you loue me▪

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Well: Ile go to make her loath the ſhame ſhee's in, The 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p:
The • ight of vi • e 〈◊〉 the • ate o • ſinne, very •••
perdy.

div.head: Scena Secunda.

stage.hi: Enter Coclo •• moy • and Mary Faugh.

sp.speaker: Coclo:
sp.p: Mary, Mary Faugh.

sp.speaker: Marc
sp.p: H • m.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Come any worſhipfull 〈…〉 any blew tooth'd Patrones of 〈…〉 wickedneſſe, giue me the gobletts.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p:
By yea, and by nay, maiſter Coclod ••
I feare you're play the knaue and reſtore them.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p:
No by the Lord A •• ,
〈◊〉 Catholi •• e and 〈◊〉 know'ſt we loue.

sp.speaker: Mar▪
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p:
Oracles are ſeas'd: Tempu • pr • t •••• , do'ſt heare my • orſhipfull gliſterpipe, thou vngodly fyer that burnt Diana •
〈◊〉 , do'ſt heare Ba • d,

In very good truthnes you are the fouleſt mou •• 'd propha • ne railing Brother, call a womā the moſt vngodly 〈◊〉 : I 〈◊〉 we all eate of the forbidden fruite, and for mine
owne part tho I am one of the family of loue and as they ſay a bawd that couers the multitude of ſinnes, yet I truſt I am none of the wicked that eate fiſh a Fridaies.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p:
Hang toaſtes, I raile at thee my worſhipfull organ bellowes that fills the pipes, my fine ratling fleamy cough a the lunges and cold with a Po •• , I raile at thee what my right pretious pandres ſupportres of Barbar Surgeons and inhauntres of lati ••••
and dyet drinke: I raile at thee neceſſary damnation, Ile make an oration, I, in praiſe of thy moſt courtly in faſhion, and moſt pleaſureable function. I.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: I prethee do, I loue to heare my ſelfe prais'd, as well as any old Ladie, I.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p:
Liſt then, a Band, firſt for he • profeſſion or ye can •• i • is moſt worſhipfull of all the 12. Companies, for as that trade it moſt honorable that ſells the beſt comōdityes, as the Draper is more worſhipfull then the poyntmaker, the ſilkeman more worſhipfull then the Draper, and the Goldſmith more honorable then both, Little Mary ſo, that 〈◊〉
• hon • all, her ſho •• has the beſt were, for where theſe • ell but 〈◊〉 ſattens, and 〈…〉 ſels diuine vertues as virginitie, modeſtie and ſuch rare I • mmes, and thoſe not like a petty chapman, by retaile, but like a great marchant hy whole • ale,
•• , ha, ho, and who are her cuſtomers, not baſe corn cutters, or ſowgelders, but moſt ra • e wealthie Knightes, and moſt 〈…〉 are her cuſtomers 〈…〉 profite, but by the loſſe and diſpleaſure of another, as the Marchant thriues non but by the licentiouſnes of giddie, and vnſetled youth: the Lawyer, but by (the vexation of his client, the Phiſition, but by the maladies of his patient, onely my ſmothe gumbde Bawd hues by others pleaſure, and onely growes rich by other riſing. O mercifull gaine, O righteous in-come. So much for her voca ••• on, trade and life, as for their death, how can it bee 〈…〉 their wickedneſſe is alwayes before their eyes, and a deathes head moſt commonly on their middle finger. To conclude, ti's moſt certaine they muſt needes both liue well, and d • e well, ſince 〈◊〉 commonly they liue in Clearken-well, and dye in 〈…〉
Dixi Mary.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Come along, yonders the preface or exordium to my wench, the bawde: Fetch, fetch. What M. Cocledemoy, is your knaueſhippe yet ſtirring, looke to it, Mulligrub lyes for you.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: The more foole he, I can lye for my ſelfe, worſhipfull friend, hang toaſtes, I vanniſh. Ha my fine boy thou art a ſcholler, and haſt read Tullies Offices, my fine knaue, hang toaſtes.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The Vintner will toaſt you and he catch you.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: I will draw the Vintner to the ſtoope, and when he runs low tilt him, he my fine knaue, art going to thy recreation.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes my capticeous raskall.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Thou wilt looke like a foole then by and by.

sp.speaker: Free
sp.p: Looke like a foole why?

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Why according to the old ſaying, A begger when he is lowſing of himſelfe lookes like a Philoſopher, a hard bound Philoſopher, when he is on the ſtoole, lookes like a tyrant, and a 〈…〉 when hee is in his be • y 〈◊〉 , lookes like a foole, God gi • e your worſhip good reſt, grace and mercy keepe your Syring ſtraight, and your Lotium vnſpile.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: See, Sir this is ſhe.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: This?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: This.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A Curteſan? Now cold bloud defend me, what a proportion afflictes me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O mine aderliuer loue, vat ſall me do to requi • dis your muſt affection.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Marry ſalute my friend, clippe his necke, and kiſſe him welcome.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A mine art, Sir you bin very velcome.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Kiſſe her man with a more familiar affection, ſo, come what entertainement, goe to your Lute. Exit Fran.

And how doſt approue my ſomtimes elected? fees none of your ramping Cannibals, that deuoure mās fleſh, nor any of your curtian gulfes, that will neuer be ſatisfied, vntill the beſt thing 〈◊〉
has be throwne into them. I lou'd her with my heart, vntill my ſoule ſhewed me the imperfection of my body, and placed my affection on a lawful loue, my modeſt Beatrice, which if this ſhort heeles knew, there were no being for mee with eyes before her face. But faith▪ doſt thou not ſome what excuſe my ſometimes incontinency with her enforciue beauties. Speake.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Hah, ſhe is a whore, is ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: VVhore? fie whore? you may call her a Curtezan, a Cocatrice, or (as that worthy ſpirite of an eternall happineſſe ſaide) a Suppoſitarie, but whore? fie: tis not in faſhion to call thinges by their right names, is a great marchant, a coockold, you muſt ſay, he is one of the liuery, is a great Lord, a foole, you muſt ſay he is weake, is a gallant pocky, you muſt ſay, he has the court 〈◊〉 , come ſhees your miſtreſſe or ſo: Enter Franciſchina with her Lute. Come Syren your voice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Vill not you ſtay in mine boſome to night loue▪

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: By no meanes ſweet breaſt, this Gentleman has vowde to ſee me chaſtly layde.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He ſhall haue a bedde too, if dat it pleaſe him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Peace you tender him offence, hee is one of a profeſſed abſtinence, Syren your voyce and away.

lg.head: The Song.
lg.l: I loue to ſleepe gainſt prickle.

sp.p: Thankes, Buſſe, ſo the night growes old good re •• .

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Reſt to mine deare loue, reſt, and no long abſence.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Beleeue me not long.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sall Ick not beleeue you long. Exit Fraciſchina.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: O yes, come viah, away, boy, on. Exit his Page lighting him

div.stage: Enter Freuill and ſeemes to ouerheare Malheureus.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Is ſhe vnchaſt, can ſuch a one be damde?
O loue and beautie, yee two eldeſt ſeedes
Of the vaſt Chaos, what ſtrong right you haue,
Euen in thinges diuine, our very ſoules.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Wha, ha, ho, come bird come, ſtand peace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Are ſtrumpets then ſuch things, ſo delicate,
Can cuſtome ſpoile, what nature made ſo good.
Or is their Cuſtome bad? Beauti's for vſe,
I neuer ſaw a ſweet face vitious,
It might be proud, inconſtant, wanton, nice,
But neuer tainted with vnnaturall vice.
Their worſt is, their beſt art is loue to winne,
O that to loue ſhould be or ſhame, or ſinne;

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: By the Lord hee's caught, Laughter eternall?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Soule I muſt loue her deſteny is weake to my affection.
A common loue, bluſh not faint breaſt
That which is euer loued of moſt is b •••
Let colder-eld the ſtrongſt obiections mo •• ,
No lou's without ſome luſt, • o life without ſome loue.

sp.speaker: Eree:
sp.p: Nay come on good ſir, what though the moſt odious ſpectacle the world can preſent be an imōdeſt vulgar woman: Yet ſir for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Well ſir for your ſake Ile thinke better of them.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Doe good ſir and pardon me that haue brought you in You knowe the ſight of vice augments the hate of ſinne.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Hah? will you go home ſir 'tis hye bed time.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Withall my hart ſir only do not chide me I muſt confeſſe.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: A wanton louer you haue been.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: O that to loue ſhould be or ſhame, or ſinne.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Say yee?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Let colder eld the ſtrongſt obiections mooue.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Howe's this?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.l: No loue's without ſome luſt,
No life without ſome loue,
sp.p:
go your wayes for an Apoſtata, I beleue my caſt garment muſt be let out in the ſeames for you when all is done,
"Of all the fooles that would all man out-thruſt,
"He that 'gainſt Nature would ſeeme wiſe is worſt.

div.head: Actus Secundus. Scena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Ereeuile, pages with torches, and gentlemen with muſicke.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.l: The morne is yet but younge: here gentlemen,
This is my Beatrice window, this the chamber
Of my betrothed deareſt, whoſe chaſte eyes,
Full of lou'd ſweetneſſe, and cleare cherefulnes,
Haue gag'd my ſoule to her in ioyings,
Shredding away all thoſe weake vnder-braunches,
Of baſe affections, and vnfruitfull heates,
Here beſtow your muſick to my voyce. Cantat.
Alwaies a vertuous name to my chaſt loue,

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Lou'd ſir the honor of your wiſh returne to you,
I cannot with a miſtres complement
Forced diſcourſſes, or nice art of wit,
Giue entertaine to your deere wiſhed preſence,
But ſafely thus, what harty gratefulnes,
Vnſulleine Silence, vnaffected modeſty,
And an vnignorant ſhamefaſtnes can expreſſe,
Receiue as your proteſted due. Faith my hart,
I am your ſeruant,
O let not my ſecure ſimplicity, breed your miſlike,
As one quite voyde of ſkill,
Tis Grace inough in vs not to be ill,
I can ſome good, and faith I mean no hurt,
Do not then ſweete wrong ſober ignorance,
I iudge you all of vertue, and our vowes,
Should kill all feares that baſe diſtruſt can mooue,
my ſoule what ſay you, ſtill you loue?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.l: Still? my vowe is vp aboue me, & like time
Irrevocable. I am ſworne all yours,
No beauty ſhall vntwine our armes, no face
In my eyes can or ſhall ſeeme faire,
And would to God only to me you might
Seeme only faire; let others diſeſteeme
Your matchles graces: ſo might I ſafer ſeeme,
Enuie I couet not: far, far be all oſtent
Vaine boaſts of beauties: ſoft ioyes and the reſt,
"He that is wiſe, pants, on a priuate breſt,
So could I liue in deſart moſt vnknowne,
Your ſelfe to me enough were Populous,
Your eyes ſhall be my ioyes, my wine that ſtill
Shall drowne my often cares, your onely voyce
Shall caſt a ſlumber on my liſtning ſence,
You with ſoft lip ſhall onely ope mine eyes,
And ſucke theire lidds a ſunder, onely you
Shall make me wiſh to liue, & not feare death,
So on your cheekes I might yeild lateſt breath,
O he that thus may liue, and thus ſhall dye,
May well be enuied of a dietie.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: Deare my lou'd hart be not ſo paſſionate, nothing extreame liues long.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: "But not to be extreame, nothing in loue's extreame my loue receiues no meane.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: I giue you fayth, and pre thee ſince poore foule I am ſo eaſy to beleeue thee, make it much more pitty to deceiue me, weare this ſleight fauor in my remēbrance. throweth downe a ring to him.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Which when I part from, hope the beſt of life, euer part from me.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: I take you and your word, which may euer liue your ſeruant, ſee day is quite broke vp, the beſt of houres.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Good morrow gracefull miſtres, our nuptiall day holds.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: With happy conſtancy a wiſhed day. Exit.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: My ſelfe and all content reſt with you.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: The ſtudious morne with paler cheeke drawes on,
The dayes bold light, harke how the free-borne birdes
Caroll their vnaffected paſſions, The Nitingalls ſing.
Now ſing they ſonnets, thus they crye, we loue
O breath of heauen! thus they harmles ſoules
Giue intertaine to mutuall affects.
They haue no Baudes: no mercenary bedds
No politike reſtraints: no artificiall heats
No faint diſſemblings, no cuſtome makes them bluſh,
No ſhame afflicts theire name, O you happy beaſtes
In whome an inborne heat is not held ſinne,
How far tranſcend you wretched, wretched man
Whome nationall cuſtome, Tyrannous reſpects
Of ſlauiſh order, fetters: lames his power
Calling that ſinne in vs, which in all thi ••• els
Is natures higheſt vertue. (O miſeri quer ••• ng gaud a crimen haben •
Sure nature againſt vertue croſſe doth fall
Or vertues ſelfe is oft vnnaturall,
That I ſhould loue a ſtrumpet I a man of Snowe
Now ſhame forſake me whether am I fallen!
A creature of a publique vſe, my frendes loue to
To liue to be a talke to men, a ſhame
To my profeſſed vertue. "O accurſed reaſon,
"How many eyes haſt thou to ſee thy ſhame▪
"And yet how blind once to preuent defame?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Diaboli vertus in Lumbis eſt, morrow my frend; come, I could make a tedious ſcene of this now but, what, pab, thou art in loue with a Courtezan, why ſir, ſhould we loath all ſtrumpet aſume men ſhould hate their owne mothers or ſiſters, a ſinne againſt kinde I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: May it be ſeeme a wiſe man to be in loue?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Let wiſe men alone, twill beſeeme thee and me well enough.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Shall I not offend the 〈…〉 of our frendſhip?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p:
Wher to affect that 〈…〉
• rend affected by hea
• en I reſigne her freely, the creature and I moſt growe of, by this time ſhee has aſſurely heard of my reſolued marriage, and no queſtion ſweares, Gods Sacrament, • en Towſand Diuells Ile reſigne I faith.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: I would but imbrace her, • eare her ſpeake, and at the moſt but kiſſe her.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: O frend he that could liue with the ſmoake of roaſt •• ate might liue at a cheape rate.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: I ſhall neere prooue hartely receiued,
A kinde of flat vngratious modeſty,
An inſufficient dul • es ſtaines my hauiour.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No matter ſir, In-ſufficiency and ſottiſhnes are much commendable in a moſt diſcommendable action, now could I ſwallow thee, thou hadſt wont to be ſo ba • ſh and cold ile tell thee. Hell and the prodegies of angrie loue are not ſo fearefull to a thinking minde as a man without affectio • , why frend, Philoſophie & a ••• re are all one, lo •• , is the center in which all lines cloſe the common bonde of being.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: O but a chaſt reſerued priuatnes, a modeſt continence,

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.l: He tell thee what, take this as firmeſt ſence,
"In Continence will force a Continence,
"Hea • e waſteth heate, light defaceth light,
"Nothing is ſpoyled but by his proper might,
This is ſome thing too waighty for thy floore▪

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But how ſo ere you ſhade it, the worlds eye
Shines not and open out,
Lying, malice, enuie, are held but fidyngs.
〈◊〉 of rage, when cuſtome and the world
Calls luſt a crime ſpotted with blackeſt terrore▪

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Where errors are held Crimes, 〈◊〉 are but errors
Along ſi • to her ſhee is an • rrand ſtrumpet: & a ſtrumpet is.

A Sarpego • Venom de 〈◊〉 to man. (Off ••
〈…〉 .
Things •• tually poſſeſſed: yet 〈…〉
And againe as good make vſe of a Statue,
A body without a ſoule, a carkaſſe three monethes dead,
Yet ſince thou art in loue.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Death man, my deſtiny I cannot chooſe.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Nay I hope ſo, againe they fell but onely fleſh,
No iot affection, ſo that euen in the enioying,
Abſentem marmore amque p • tes, yet ſince you needs muſt loue,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Vnauoidable though folly, worſe then madnes.

sp.speaker: Free,
sp.l: Its true, but ſince you needs m • ſt loue, you muſt know this,
He that muſt loue, a foole, and he muſt kiſſe,

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Ago tibi gratias, my worſhipfull friend, how do'es your friend?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Out you raſcall.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Hang toaſtes, you are an Aſſe, much a your worſhips brayne lyes in your Calues, bread a God boy, I was at ſupper laſt night with a new weande bulchin, bread a God drunke, horribly drunke, horribly drunke, there was a wench one Franke Frailty, a puncke, an honeſt pole-cat, of a cleane In ſtep, found legge, ſmooth thigh, and the nimble Diuell in her buttocke, al • fieſt a grace, when ſaw you Tyſefew, or M. Caque • ure, that pratling gallant of a good draught common cuſtomes, fortunate, impudence and ſound fare.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: A way Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cocl,
sp.p: Hang toaſtes, my fine boy, my companion as worſhipfull.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yes I heare you are taken vp with ſchollers and churchmen. Enter Hol • fernes the Barbar.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p:
Qùanquam to Marce fi ••
my fine boy, does your worſhip want a Barb • Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Farewell knaue, beware the Mull • grubs.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Let the Malligrubs beware the knaue, what a Barbar Surgeon▪ my delicate boy?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: Yes ſir an apprentiſe to ſurgery.
Ti,s my fine boy, to what bawdy 〈◊〉 doth your Maiſter belong, whats thy name?

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Rainſcure? good M. Holifernes I deſire your further acquaintance, nay pray yee bee couered my fine boy, kill thy itch and heale thy skabes, is thy Maiſter rotten?

sp.speaker: Holif.
sp.p: My father forſooth is dead.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: And laid in his graue, alas what comfort ſhall Peggy then haue.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: None but me ſir, thats my mothers ſonne I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Mothers ſonne, a good witty boy, would liue to read an Homilie well, and to whome are you going now?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Marry forſooth to trim M. Mulligrub
• he Vintner.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Doe you know M. Mulligrub?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: My Godfather Sir.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Good boy hold vp thy chops, I pray thee doe one thing for me, my name is Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: good M. Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Lend me thy baſon, razer, and Apron.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: O Lord ſir.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Wel ſpokē, good engliſh, but whats thy furniture worth?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: O Lord ſir I know not.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Well ſpoken, a boy of a good wit, holde this pawne, where doſt dwell.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: At the ſigne of the three razers ſir,

sp.speaker: Cocl
sp.p: A ſigne of good ſhauing my caraſtrophonicall fine boy, I haue an odde ieſt to trim M. Mulligrub for a wager, a ieſt boy, a humor, Ile returne thy thinges preſently, hold.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: What meane you good M. Gudgeon?

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Nothing faith but a ieſt boy, drinke that, Ile recoile preſently.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: You'le not ſtay long.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: As I am an honeſt man, the 3. razers?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: I ſir. Exit Holifernes.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p:
Good, and if I ſhaue not M. Mulligrub, my wit has no edge, and I may goe cacke in my pewter, let me ſee, a Barbar, my ſcurule tongue will diſcouer me, muſt diſſemble, muſt diſguiſe, for my beard, my falſe hayre, for my tongue Spaniſh Dutch, or Welſh, no, a Northerne Barbar, very good, widdow Raine-ſ • ures man well, newly entertainde, right, to, hang toſtes, a •• cardes
haue white backes, and all knaues would ſeeme to haue white breaſter, ſo proceede, now worſhipfull Cocledemoy.

div.stage: Exit Cocledemoy in his Barbars furniture.
Enter Marie Eough, and Eranciſchina with her Harye, Looſe chafing.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Nay good ſweete daughter, doe not ſwagger ſo, you heare your loue is to bee married, true, he does caſt you off, right he will leaue you to the world, what then? tho blew and white, black and greene leaue you, may not redde and yellow entertain you, is there but one coullor in the Raine-bow?

sp.speaker: Franciſ.
sp.p: Grand Grincome on your ſentences, Gods ſacrament, ten towſand diuels take you, you ha brought mine loue, mine honor, mine boddy all to noting.

sp.speaker: Mary Fough.
sp.p: To nothing! I'le be ſworne I haue brought them to all the thinges I could, I ha made as much a your maydenhead, and you had beene mine owne daughter, I could not ha ſold your Mayden head oftner then I ha done, I ha ſworn for you God forgiue me, I haue made you acquainted with the Spaniard Don Skirtoll, with the Italian, M. Beieroane, with the Iriſh Lord, S. Patrick, with the Dutch Marchant, Haunc • Herkin G • ukin Skellam Elappdragon, and ſpecially with the greateſt French, and now laſtly with this Engliſh (yet in my conſcience) an honeſt Gentleman: and am I now growne one of the accurſed with you for my labour? is this my reward, am I calde Bawde? Well Mary Fough, goe thy wayes Mary Fough, thy kind heart will bring thee to the Hoſpitall.

sp.speaker: Franciſc.
sp.p: Nay good Naunt, you'le helpe me to an oder loue, vil you not?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Out thou naughty belly, wouldſt thou make mee thy Bawde? thu'ſt beſt make me thy Bawde, I ha kept counſell for thee, who paide the Apothecary, waſt not honeſt Mary Fough? who redeemde thy petticote and mantle, waſt not honeſt Mary Fough? who helped thee to thy cuſtome not of ſwaggering Ireand Captaines, nor of 2. s. Innes a court men, but with honeſt atte-cappes, wealthy flat-caps, that pay for their pleaſure the beſt of any men in Europe, nay, which is more in London, and doſt thou defile me vile creature.

sp.speaker: Franciſ.
sp.p: Foutra pon you Vitch, Bawde, Pole-catte, Paugh, did not you prayſe Freeuill to mine loue?

sp.speaker: Fough.
sp.p: I did prayſe I confeſſe, I did prayſe him, I ſede hee was a foole, an vnthrift, a true whoremaiſter, I confeſſe, a conſtāt drabbe keeper I confeſſe, but what the winde is turnde.

sp.speaker: Eranciſ.
sp.p: It is, it is vile woman, reprobate wowan, naughtie woman it is, vat sal become of mine poore fleſh now, mine boddy muſt turne Turke for 2. d. O Diuela, life a mine art, Ick sall be reuengde, doe ten thouſand Hell damme me, Ick sal haue the rouge trote cut, and his loue, and his friend, and all his affinitie ſall ſmart, ſall dye, ſal hang, now legion of deuill ſeaze him, de gran peſt, S. Anthonies fire, and de hot Neopolitan poc rotte him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O mine ſeete, deerſt, kindeſt, mine louing, O mine towſand, ten towſand, delicated, petty ſeet art Cantat Gallice. a mine a deere leeueſt affection.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why Monky, no faſhion in you? giue entertaine to my friend.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Icke ſal make de moſt of you, dat curteſie may: Aunt Mary, Mettre Faugh, ſtooles, ſtooles for des gallantes: mine Mettre ſing non oder ſong, frolique, frolique Sir, but ſtill complaine me doe her wrong, lighten your heart Sir, for me did but kiſſe her, for me did but kis her, and ſo let go: Your friend is very heauy, ick ſall neere like ſuch ſad company.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No thou delighteſt onely in light Company.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.p: By mine trot, he been very ſad, vat ayle you ſir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A tooth ake Lady, a paultry rheume.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: De diet is very goot for de rheume.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: How far of dwels the houſe ſurgeon Mary Fough.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You are a prophane fellow I faith, I little thought to heare ſuch vngodly termes come from your lips.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pre de now, tis but a toy, a very trifle.

sp.speaker: Free
sp.p: I care not for the valew, Franke, but I faith-

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
I fait, me muſt needes haue it (dis is Beatrice ring, oh
could I get it,) ſeet pree de now, as euer you haue embraced me with a hearty arme, a warme thought, or a pleaſing touch, as euer you will profeſſe to loue me, as euer you do wiſh me life, giue me dis ring, dis litle ring.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Pree thee be not vnciuillie importunate, ſha not ha't, faith I care not for thee, nor thy ielouſie, ſha not ha't ifaith.

sp.speaker: Franciſ:
sp.p: You doe not loue me, I heare of Sir Hubert Subboys daughter Miſtreſſe Beatrice, Gods Sacrament, ick could ſcratch out her eyes, and ſucke the holes.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Goe y' are growne a puncke rampant.

sp.speaker: Franciſ.
sp.p: So get thee gone, nere more behold min eyes by thee made wretched.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Mary Fough farewell, farewell Franck.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: Sall I not ha de ring?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: No by the Lord.

sp.speaker: Franck:
sp.p: By te Lord?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: By the Lord.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Goe to your new Blouze, your vnproude ſluttery, your modeſt Mettre forſooth.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Marry will I forſooth.

sp.speaker: Franck:
sp.p: Will you marry forſooth?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.l: Doe not turne witch before thy time.
With all my hart Sir, you will ſtay.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I am no whit my ſelfe, Ʋideo meliora proboque,
But raging luſt my fate all ſtrong doth moue:
"The Gods themſelues cannot be wiſe and loue.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Your wiſhes to you. Exit Freeuil:

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Beautie entirely choyce:

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.p: Pray yee proue a man of faſhion, and neglect the neglected.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Can ſuch a raritie bee neglected, can there be meaſure or ſinne in louing ſuch a creature▪

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O min poore forſaken hart.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: I can not containe, he ſaw thee not that left thee,
If there be wiſedome, reaſon, honor, grace
Of any fooliſhly eſteemed vertue,
In giuing o're poſſeſſion of ſuch beautie,
Let me be vitious, ſo I may be lou'de,
Paſſion I am thy ſlaue, ſweete it ſhall be my grace,
That I account thy loue, my onely vertue:
Shall I ſweare I am thy moſt vowed ſeruant.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mine vowed, go, go, go, I can no more of loue, no, no, no, you bin all vnconſtant, O vnfaithfull men, tyrantes, betrayers, de very enioying vs, looſeth us, and when you onely ha made vs hatefull, you onely hate vs: O mine forſaken hart.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I muſt not raue, Scilence and modeſty two cuſtomarie vertues: will you be my miſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Franc:
sp.p: Mettres? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: VVill you lie wirh me?

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Lie with you, O no, you men will out-lie any woman, f • i • me no more can loue.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: No matter, let me enioy your bed.

sp.speaker: Franc,
sp.p: O vile man, vat do you tinck on me, doe you take mee to be a beaſt, a creature that for ſence onely will entertaine loue, and not onely for loue, loue? O brutiſh abhomination!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: VVhy then I pray thee loue, and with thy loue enioy me.

sp.speaker: Franc:
sp.p: Giue me reaſon to affect you, will you ſweare you loue me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: So ſeriouſly, that I proteſt no office ſo dangerous, no deede ſo vnreaſonable, no coſt ſo heauie, but I vow to the vtmoſt tentation of my beſt being to effect it.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Sall I, or can I truſt againe? O foole,
How naturall tis for vs to be abuſde!
Sall ick be ſure that no ſatietie,
No inoying, not time ſhall languiſh your affection?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: If there be ought in brayne, hart or hand,
Can make you doubtleſſe, I am your vowed ſeruant.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: VVill you doe one ting for me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Can I doe it?

sp.speaker: Eranc.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but ick doe not loue dis ſame Freeuill.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: VVell.

sp.speaker: Eranc.
sp.p: Nay I do hate him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Eranc.
sp.p: By this kiſſe I hate him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I loue to feele ſuch othes, ſweare againe.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: No, no, did you euer heare of any that loude at the firſt ſight?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A thing moſt proper.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Now fai • , I iudge it all incredible, vntill this houre I ſaw you pritty fayre eyed yout, would you enioy me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Rather then my breath, euen as my being.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Vel, had ick not made a vow.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: VVhat vow?

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: O let me forget it, it makes vs both deſpaire.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Deare ſoule what vow?

sp.speaker: Franck:
sp.p: Hah, good morrow gentle Sir, endeuour to forget me, as I muſt be enforced to forget al lmen. Sweet mind reſt in you.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Stay, let not my deſire burſt me, O my impatient heate endures no reſiſtance, no protractiō, there is no being for me but your ſuddaine inioying.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: I doe not loue Freeuil.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: But what vow, what vow?

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: So long as Freeuil liues, I muſt not loue.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Then he.

sp.speaker: Franc:
sp.p: Muſt.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Die.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I, no there is no ſuch vehemence in your affectes,
VVould I were any thing, ſo he were not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: VVill you be mine when he is not?

sp.speaker: Franc
sp.p: VVill I? deare, deare breaſt, by this moſt zealous kiſſe, but I will not perſwade you: but if you hate him that I loath moſt deadly, yet as you pleaſe, i'le perſwade noting.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: VVill you be onely mine.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.p: Vill I? how hard tis for true loue to diſſemble, I am onely yours.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Tis as irreuocable as breath, he dyes. Your loue.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.l: My vow, not vntill hee be dead,
VVhich that I may be ſure not to infringe,
Dis token of his death, ſall ſatisfie,
He has a ring, as deare as the ayre to him,
His new loues gift: tat got and brought to me.
I ſhall aſſured your pofeſſed reſt.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: To kill a man?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O done ſafely, a quarrell ſuddain pickt,
with an aduantage ſtrike, then bribe, a little coyne,
Al's ſafe, deare ſoule, but Ile not ſet you on,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay hee is gone, the ring, well, come, little more liberall of thy loue.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Not yet my vow.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: O heauen, there is no hell but loues prolongings, deare farewell.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Farewell, Now does my hart ſwell high, for my reuenge,
Has birth and forme, firſt friend • al kill his friend,
He dat ſuruiues, i'le hang, beſides'de
Chaſt Beatrice ile vexe▪ onely de ring.
Dat got the world ſall know the worſt of euils.
"VVoman corrupted is the 〈◊〉 of deuils. Exit Fran.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To kill my friend▪ O • is to kill my ſelfe,
Yet mans but mans excrement, 〈◊〉 breeding man,
As he do's wormes 〈…〉 this nothing, he ſ • its.
The body of a man is of the ſelfe ſame ſoule,
A's Oxe or horſe, no murther 〈◊〉 theſe,
As for that onely part, which makes •• man,
Murther wa •• powe • to 〈◊〉 O wit how vile,
How helliſh art thou, when thou • ffect nature
Gainſt ſacred faith▪ thinke mo • e to kill a friend

To gaine a woman, to Io • ſo •
〈◊〉 ſelfe,
For appetite and ſenſual end, whoſe very hauing,
Looſeth all appetite, and giues • a •• etie,
That corporall end, remorſe and inward bluſhinges,
Forcing vs loath the ſteame of our owne heates,
VVhilſte friendſhip cloſde in vertue being ſpiritual,
Taſtes no ſuch languiſhinges and moments pleaſure,
VVith much repentance, but like riuers flow,
And further that they runne, they bigger grow,
Lord how was I miſgone, how eaſie ti's to erre,
VVhen paſſion wil not giue vs leaue to thinke?
"A learn'd that is an honeſt man may feare.
"And luſt, and rage, and malice, and any thing,
"when he is taken vncollected ſuddenly:
"Ti's ſinne of colde blood; miſchiefe wil • wak'd eyes,
"That is the damned and the truely vice,
"Not he that's paſſionles but he 'boue paſſion's wiſe,
My friend ſhall know it all. Exit:

div.stage: Enter Maiſter Mulligrub, and Miſtreſſe Mulligrub, ſhee with bag of money.

sp.speaker: Mistreſſe Mul.
sp.p: It is right I aſſure you, iuſt fifteene pounds.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Well Cocledemoy tis thou putſt me to this charge, but and I catch thee, I'le charge thee with as many irons: well, is the Barbar come, ile be trimd and then to Cheapeſide, to buy a faire peece of plate, to furniſh the loſſe, is the Barbar come?

sp.speaker: Miſt: Mul:
sp.p: Truth husband, ſurely heauen is not pleaſde with our vocation; we do winke at the ſinnes of our people, our wines are Proteſtantes, and I ſpeake it to my griefe, and to the burthē of my conſcience, we frie our fiſh with ſalt butter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Goe looke to your buſines, mend the matter and skore falfe with a vengeance.
Welcome friend, whoſe man?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Widdow Raine ſoures man, and ſhall pleaſe your good worſhip, my nam'es Andrew Sharke.

sp.speaker: M. Mul:
sp.p: How do's my God ſonne good Andrew.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Very well, hee's gone to trim M. Quicquid our Parſon, hold vp your head.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: How long haue you beene a Barbar Andrew?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Not long Sir, this two yeare.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: What and a good worke man already, I dare ſcarſe truſt my heade to thee.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: O feare not, we ha polde better men then you, we learn the trade very quickly, will your good worſhip be ſhaue not 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: As you will, what trade didſt liue by, before thou turnedſt Barbar Andrew.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: I was a Pedler in Germany, but my countrimen thriue better by this trade.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Wha's the newes Barbar, thou art ſometimes at Court.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Sometimes pole a Page or ſo ſir.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: And what's the newes? how doe all my good Lordes, and all my good Ladies, and all the reſt of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: What an arrogant knaue's this, Ile acquaintance yee (tis caſh,) ſay yee ſir. hee ſpieth the bag

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: And what newes? what newes? good Andrew.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Marry ſir you know the Conduit at Greenewich, and the vnder-holes that ſpowtes vp water.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Very well, I was waſht there one day, and ſo was my wiſe, you might haue wrung her ſmocke ifaith, but what a thoſe holes?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Thus Sir, out of thoſe little holes in the midſt of the night crawlde out 24. huge horrible, monſtrous, fearefull deuouring.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Bleſſe vs.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Serpents, which no ſooner were beheld, but they turnd to maſſiues which howlde, thoſe maſtiues inſtantly turnde to Cockes which crowed, thoſe cockes in a moment were changde to Beares which roard, which Beares are at this hower to bee yet ſcene in Paris Garden, liuing vpon nothing but toaſted cheeſe and greene onions.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: By the Lord and this may be: my wife and I will go ſee them, this portends ſomething.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Yes worſhipfull Fieſt, thou'ſt feele what portendes by and by.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: And what more newes, you ſhaue the worlde, eſpecially you Barbar Surgeons you know the ground of many thinges, you are cunning priuie ſearchers, by the mas you skowre all: what more newes?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: They ſay Sir that 25, coople of Spaniſh Iennetes are to bee ſeene hand in hand daunce the olde meaſures, whileſt fixe goodly Flaunders Mares play to them on a noyſe of flutes.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: O monſtrous! this is a lie a my word, nay and this bee not a lie, I am no foole I warrant, nay make an Aſſe of mee once?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Shut your eyes cloſe, wincke ſure ſir, this bal wil make you ſmart.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: I do winke.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Your head will take cold.
sp.stage: Cocledemoy puts on a Coxe combe on Mulligrubs head.
sp.p:
I will put on your good worſhips night-cap, whileſt I ſhaue you, ſo, much: hang toaſtes: faugh: viah: ſparrowes muſt pecke and
Cocledemoy munch.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, 25. couple of Spaniſh Iennets to daunce the olde meaſures. Andrew, makes my worſhippe laugh, ifaith, doſt take me for an Aſſe Andrew, doſt know one Cocledemoy in towne, he made mee an Aſſe laſt night, but ile aſſe him, art thou free Andrew, ſhaue me well, I ſhall bee one of the common Councell ſhortly, and then Andrew, why Andrew, Andrew, doeſt leaue me in the Suddes? Cantat. why Andrew I ſhall be blinde with winking. Ha Andrew, wife Andrew, what meanes this, wife, my money wife.

sp.speaker: Miſtreſſe Mul.
sp.p: What's the noyſe with you? what aile you?

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: VVheres the Barbar?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mul.
sp.p: Gone, I ſaw him depart long ſinne, why are not you trimd?

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: Trimd, O wife, I am ſhau'd, did you take hence the money?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mul.
sp.p: I toucht it not as I am Religious▪

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: O Lord I haue wink faire.

sp.speaker: Holof:
sp.p: I pray Godfather giue me your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: O Holofernes, O wheres thy mothers Andrew •

sp.speaker: Holof:
sp.p: Bleſſing Godfather.

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: The diuell choake thee, where's Andrew thy mothers man?

sp.speaker: Holof:
sp.p: My mother hath none ſuch forſooth.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: My money, 15. l. plague of all Andrewes, who waſt trimd me?

sp.speaker: Holof:
sp.p: I know not Godfather, onelie one me •… me, as I was comming to you, and borrowed my furniture, as he ſaide for a ieſt ſake.

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: What kinde of fellow?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: A thick elderly ſtub-bearded fellow.

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: Cocledemoy, Cocledemoy, raiſe all the Wiſe men in the ſtreete, Ile hang him with mine owne hands O wife, ſome R • ſa Solis.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mul
sp.p:
Good husband take comfort in the Lord, Ile play the Diuell, but ile recouer it, haue a good conſcience ti's but a
weekes cutting in the Terme.

sp.speaker: M. Mul:
sp.p: O wife, O wife, O Iacke how does thy mother? is there any Fidlers in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mul.
sp.p: Yes, M. Creakes noyſe.

sp.speaker: M Mul.
sp.p: Bid 'em play, laugh, make merry, caſt vp my accountes, for ile go hang my ſelfe preſently, I will not curſe, but a poxe on Cocledemoy, he has polde and ſhaude the, he has trimd me. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus tertius. Scena prima.

stage.hi: Enter Beatrice, Criſpinell, and Nurs Putif • r.

sp.speaker: Puti.
sp.p: Nay good child, A loue once more, M. Freeuils Sonnet, a the kiſſe you gaue him.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.l: Sha'te good Nurſe,
Pureſt lips ſoft banks of bliſſes,
Selfe alone, deſeruing kiſſes,
O giue me leaue to &c.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p:
Piſh ſiſter Beatrice,
〈◊〉 thee reade no more, my ſtomacke alate ſtands againſt kiſſing extreamly.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Why good Criſpinell ••

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: By the faith, and truſt I beare to my face, tis grown one of the moſt vnſauorie Ceremonies▪ Boddy, a • eautie tis one of the moſt vnpleaſing in 〈…〉 fellow that 〈◊〉 but one no • on 〈◊〉 , and ſtanding co •• r and ſkirtes alſo •• ude with Taſtery ſarcenet, muſt ſalute vs on the lipps as •• iliarly▪ Soft ſkins ſaue yet here was a ſtubbearded Iohn a ſtile with a ploydens fa • e ſaluted me laſt day, and ſtroke his briſtles through my lippes, I • a ſpent 10. ſhillings in pom • tum finde to • kinne them againe. Marry it a nobleman or a knight with one •• he viſſit vs though his vncleane gooſe turnd greene teeth, hathe palſy his noſtrells ſmell worſe then a putrified maribone, & his looſe beard drops into our boſome, yet wee muſt kiſſe him with a curſy, a curſe, for my part I had as liue they would break wynd in my lip • s.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: Fy Criſpinella you ſpeake too broad.

sp.speaker: Crispi:
sp.p:
No • ot ſiſter, lets neere be aſhamed to ſpeake what we
be not aſhamd to thinke, I dare as boldly ſpeake venery, as think venery.

sp.speaker: Beat▪
sp.p: Faith ſiſter ile begone if you ſpeake ſo broad.

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: Will you ſo? now baſhfulnes ſeaz you, we pronoūce boldly Robbery, Murder, treaſon, which deedes muſt needes be far more lothſome then an act which is ſo naturall, iuſt and neceſſary, as that of procreation, you ſhall haue an hipocriticall veſtall virgin ſpeake, that with cloſe teeth publikely, which ſhe will receiue with open mouth priuately, for my owne part I conſider nature without apparell, without diſguiſing of cuſtome or complement, I giue thoughts wordes, and wordes truth, and truth boldnes, ſhe whoſe honeſt freenes makes it her vertue, to ſpeake what ſhe thinks, will make it her neceſſity to thinke what is good, I loue no prohibited things, and yet I would haue nothing prohibited by policy but by vertue, for as in the faſhion of time, thoſe bookes that are cald in, are moſt in ſale and requeſt; ſo in nature thoſe actions that are moſt prohibited, are moſt deſired.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: Good quick-ſiſter, ſtay your pace we are priuat, but the world would cenſure you, for truly ſeuere modeſty is womens vertue.

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: Fye, Fye,, vertue is a free pleaſant buxom qualitie: I loue a conſtant countenance well, but this froward ignorant coynes, fower auſtere lumpiſh vnciuill priuatenes, that promiſes nothing but rough ſkins, and hard ſtooles, ha, fy out good for nothing but for nothing, well nurſe, and what do you conceaue of all this?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Nay faith my conceauing dayes be done, marry for kiſſing ile defend that, thats within my compas, but for my own part heers miſtres Beatrice is to be married with the grace of God, • fine gentleman he is ſhall haue her and I warrant a ſtronge, he has a legg like a poſt, a noſe like a Lion, a brow like a Bull, and a beard of moſt faire expectation: this weeke you muſt marry him, and I now will read a lecture to you both, how you ſhall behaue your ſelues to your huſbands, the firſt monneth of your nuptiall, I ha broake my ſkull about it, I can tell you and there is much braine in it.

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: Read it to my ſiſter good nurſe, for I aſſure you ile nere marry.

sp.speaker: Put:
sp.p: Marry God forfend, what will you doe then?

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: Fayth ſtriue againſt the fleſh, marry? no fayth, huſbands are like lotts in the lottery: you may drawe forty blankes before you finde one that has any priſe in him, A huſband generally is a careles dominering thing that growes like coroll which as long as it is vnder water is ſoft and tender, but as ſoone as it has got his branch aboue the waues is preſently hard ſtiffe, not to be bowed but burſt, ſo when your husband is a ſutor & vnder your choyſe, Lord how ſuple hee is, how obſequious, how at your ſeruice ſweet Lady: once married got vp his head aboue A ſtiffe crooked knobby inflexible tyrannous creature he grows then they turne like water, more you would imbrace the leſſe you hould, ile liue my owne woman, and if the worſt come to the worſt, I had rather prooue a wagge then a foole.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: O but a vertuous marriage.

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: Vertuous marrige? there is no more affiaity betwixt vertue and marriage, then betwixt a man and his horſe, indeed vertue gerts vp vppon marriage ſometimes, and ma • ageth it in the right way, but marriage is of another peece, for as a horſe may be without a man, and a man without a horſe, ſo marriage you know is often without vertue, and vertue I am ſure more oft without marriage, but thy match ſiſter, by my troth I thinke twill do well, hees a well ſhapt cleane lipp'd gentleman of a handſome, but not affected finenes, a good faithfull eye, and a well humord cheeke, would he did not ſtoope in the ſhoulders for thy ſake, ſee here he is. (Enter Freeuill & Tiſſefew.)

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Good day Sweete.

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: Good morrow brother nay you ſhall haue my lip, good • orrow ſeruant.

sp.speaker: Tiſſe:
sp.p: Good morrow ſweete life.

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: Life? doſt call thy miſtres life.
Life, yes why not life?

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: How many miſtreſſes haſt thou?

sp.speaker: Tiſſe:
sp.p: Some nine.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Why then thou haſt nine liues like a Cat.

sp.speaker: Tiſſe.
sp.p: Mew you would be taken vp for that.

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: Nay good let me ſtill ſit, we lowe ſtatures loue ſtill to ſit, leaſt when we ſtand we may be ſuppoſed to ſit.

sp.speaker: Tiſſe:
sp.p: Doſt not weare high corke ſhooes: chopines.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Monſtrous on's. I am as many other are, peec'd aboue and peec'd beneath.

sp.speaker: Tiſſe:
sp.p: Still the beſt part in the,

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: And yet all will ſcarce make me ſo high as one of the Gyants ſtilts that ſtalkes before my Lord Maiors pageant.

sp.speaker: Tiſſe:
sp.p: By the Lord ſo I thought 'twas for ſome thing Miſtres Ioyce ieſted at thy high inſteps.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: She might well inough, and long inough, before I would be aſhamed of my ſhortnes, what I made or can mend my ſelfe I may bluſh at; but what nature put vpon me, let her be aſhamed for me, I ha nothing to doe with it, I forget my beauty.

sp.speaker: Tiſſe:
sp.p: Fayth Ioyce is a fooliſh bitter creature.

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: A pretty mildewed wench ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Tiſſe:
sp.p: And faire.

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: As my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Tiſſe:
sp.p: O you forget your beauty now.

sp.speaker: Criſp,
sp.p: Troth I neuer remember my beauty, but as ſome men doe religion for controuerſies ſake,

sp.speaker: Beat
sp.p: A motion ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Crisp,
sp.p: Niniuie, Iulius Ceaſar, Ionas, or the diſtruction of Ieruſalem.

sp.speaker: Beat,
sp.p: My loue heere.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Pree thee call him not love, 'tis the drabs phraſe, nor ſweete honie, nor my cunny, nor deare duckling, 'tis the Cittizen termes, but call me him.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Anithing, what'ſt the motion?

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: You know this night our parents haue intended ſolemnly to contract vs, and my Loue to grace the feaſt hath promiſed a maſke.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You'le make one Tyſefue, and Caqueture ſhall fill vp a rome.

sp.speaker: Tiſſe
sp.p: Fore heauen well remembred he borrowed a diamond of me laſt night to grace his finger in your viſitation: The Lying Creature will ſweare ſome ſtraung thing on it now.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Peace, he's here, ſtand cloſe, lurke.

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: Good morrow moſt deere, and worthy to be moſt wiſe, how do's my miſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: Morrow ſweete ſeruant, you gliſter, pree thee let's ſee that ſtone.

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: A toy Lady, I bought to pleaſe my finger.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Why I am more pretious to you, than your finger:

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: Yes, or than all my body, I ſweare.
Why, then let it be bought to pleaſe me, come I am no profeſſed beggar.

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: Troth Miſtreſſe; Zoones: Forſooth, I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: Nay, if you turne Proteſtant for ſuch a toy.

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: In good deed la, another time ile giue you a

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Is this yours to giue.

sp.speaker: Caque:
sp.p: O God, forſooth mine, quoth you, nay as for that.

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p:
Now I remember, I ha ſeene this on my ſeruant Tiſe
••• s finger.

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: Such another.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Nay, I am ſure this is it.

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: Troth tis forſooth, the poore fellow wanted money to pay for ſupper laſt night, and ſo pawnd it to mee, tis a pawne faith, or elſe you ſhould haue it.

sp.speaker: Tiſe:
sp.p: Harke ye, Thou baſe lying: how dares thy impudence hope to proſper, wer't not for the priuiledge of this reſpected companie, I would ſo hange thee.

sp.speaker: Criſp:
sp.p: Come hether ſeruant, What's the matter betwixt you two?

Nothing but (hearke you) he did me ſome vnciuile diſcourteſies laſt night, for which, becauſe I ſhould not call him to account, hee deſires to make me any ſatisfaction: the Coward trembles at my verie preſence, but I ha him on the hippe, ile take the forfeit on his Ringe.

sp.speaker: Tiſe:
sp.p: What's that you whiſper to her?

Nothing Sir, but ſatisfie her, that the Ringe was not pawnd, but onely lent by you to grace my finger, and ſo tould her I crau'd your pardon, for being too familiar, or indeed ouer
•••… with your reputation.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Yes indeede he did, he ſaid you deſired to make him any ſatiſfaction for an vnciuill diſcourteſie you did him laſt night, but he ſaid he had you a the hyp and would take the forfeit of your ring.

sp.speaker: Tiſe.
sp.p: How now ye baſe Pultrone?

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: Hold, hold, my miſtreſſe ſpeakes by contraries.

sp.speaker: Tiſe.
sp.p: Contraries.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: She ieſts, faith onely ieſts.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Sir, Ile no more a your ſeruice, you are a childe, Ile giue you to my nurſe.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: And he come to me, I can tell you as olde as I am, what to doe with him.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: I offer my ſeruice forſooth.

sp.speaker: Tiſe.
sp.p: Why ſo, now euery dogge has his bone to knawe on.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The Maske holds, Maſter Caque •• er.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.p: I am ready Sir, Miſtreſſe Ile daunce with you, neare feare, Ile grace you.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: I tell you I can my ſingles and my doubles and my tricke a xxtie, my carantapace, my trauerſe forward, and my falling backe yet ifaith.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Mine, the prouiſion for the night is ours.
Much muſt be our care, till night we leaue you,
I am your ſeruant be not tirannous,
Your vertue wan me, faith my loues not luſt,
Good wrong me not, my moſt fault is much truſt.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Vntill night onely my heart be with you 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Adieu brother, come on ſiſter for theſe ſince to 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Lets meete and practiſe preſently.

sp.speaker: Tiſe.
sp.p: Content, weele but fit our pumpes, Count ye 〈◊〉 vermine. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
My friend, wiſhed houres, what newes from 〈◊〉 How dos the woman of Sinne, and naturall
〈…〉

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: The eldeſt child of nature nere 〈◊〉 So dam'd a creature.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What, In noua f • x • animus 〈◊〉 dicere formas? which way beares the Tyde?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Deare loued Sir, I finde a minde courageouſly vitious, may put on a deſperate ſecuritie, but can neuer bee bleſſed with a firme inioying and ſelfe ſatiſfaction.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: what paſſion is this, my deare Lindabridis.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Tis well, we both may ieſt, I ha beene tempted to your death.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What is the rampa • t Cocatrice growne mad for the loſſe of hir men?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Deuiliſhly mad.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: As moſt aſſured of my ſecond loue.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: She would haue had this ring.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I, and this heart, and in true proofe you were ſlaine I ſhould bring her this ring, from which ſhe was aſſured
You would not part, vntill from life you parted.
For which deede, and onely for which deede, I ſhould poſſeſſe her ſweetneſſe.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: O bloody villaines, nothing is defamed but by his proper ſelfe, Phiſitions abuſe remedies, Lawyers ſpoyle the Lawe, and women onely ſhame women, you ha vow'd my death?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: My luſt, not I, before my reaſon would, yet I muſt vſe 〈◊〉 , that I a man of ſence ſhould conceiue endeleſſe pleaſure in a body whoſe ſoule I know to be ſo hideouſly blacke.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: That a man at twentie th •• e ſhould cry, O ſweete pleaſure, and at fortie three ſhould ſigh, O ſharpe Poxe: but conſider man furniſhed with omnipotencie and you ouerthrowe him, thou muſt coole thy impatient appetite.
Ti's Fate, ti's Fate.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I doe malign my creation that I am ſubiect to paſſion, I muſt inioy her.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I haue it marke, I giue a maske to night
To my loues kindred, in that thou ſhalt goe:
In that we two make ſhew of falling out,
Giue ſeeming challenge, inſtantly depart,
With ſome ſuſpition to preſent fight.
VVe will be ſeene as going to our ſwordes,
And after meeting, this Ring onely lent,
Ile lurke in ſome obſcure place, till rumor
(The common Bawde to looſe ſuſpitions)
Haue fayned me ſlaine, which (in reſpect my ſelfe
NVill not bee found, and our late ſeeming quarrell)
VVill quickly ſound to all as earneſt truth:
Then to thy wench, proteſt me ſurely dead.
Shew her this Ring, inioy her, and bloud colde
VVeele laugh at folly.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: O but thinke of it.

sp.speaker: Fre:
sp.p: Thinke of it, come away, vertue let ſleepe thy paſſions, "VVhat old times held as crimes, are now but faſhions. Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Maſter Garniſh, and Lionell: Maſter Mulligrubbe, with a ſtanding cup in his hand, and an Obligation in the other, Cocledemoy ſtands at the other dore diſguiſed like a French Pedler, and ouer-heares them.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: I am not at this time furniſhed, but ther's my bond for your Plate.

sp.speaker: Gar:
sp.p: Your bill had ben ſufficient y'are a good man, a ſtanding cup parcell guilt, of 32. ounces. 11. pound, 7. ſhillings, the firſt of Iuly, good plate, good man, good day good all.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Tis my hard fortune, I will hang the knaue, no, firſt he ſhall halfe rot in fetters in the Dungeon, his conſcience made deſpairfull, ile hyre a Knaue a purpoſe, ſhal aſſure him he is damn'd, and after ſee him with mine owne eyes, hanged without ſinging any Pſalme. Lord that hee has but one necke.

sp.speaker: Gar:
sp.p: You are too tyrannous, you'le vſe me no further.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: No Sir, lend mee your ſeruant, onely to carry the plate home, I haue occaſion of an houres abſence.

sp.speaker: Gar:
sp.p: VVith eaſie conſent, ſir haſt and be carefull, Exit Gar.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Be very carefull I pray thee to my wifes owne hands.

sp.speaker: Lion:
sp.p: Secure your ſelfe ſir.

sp.speaker: Mull:
sp.p: To her owne hand.

sp.speaker: Lion:
sp.p: Feare not, I haue deliuered greater thinges than this, to a womans owne hand.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p:
Mounſier, pleaſe you to buy a fine delicate b • ll, ſweet
ball; a Camphyer ball.

sp.speaker: Mu:
sp.p: Pre thee away.

sp.speaker: Co:
sp.p: One a ball to ſkower, a ſkowring ball, a ball to be ſhaued

sp.speaker: Mull:
sp.p: For the loue of god talke not of ſhauing, I haue been ſhaued, miſcheife and 1000. diuells ceaſe him, I haue been ſhaued. Exit Mullig:

sp.speaker: Co:
sp.p: The Fox growes fat when he is curſed, ile ſhaue ye ſmother yet, turd on a tile ſtone, my lips haue a kind of • hew • e at this bole, ile hau't, ile gargalize my throate with this Vintner, and when I haue don with him, ſpit him out, Ile ſhark, conſciēce does not repine, were I to bite an honeſt gentleman a poore grogaran poet, or a penurious Parſon, that had but ten pigs tayles in a twelue month & for want of lerning had but one good ſtoole in a fortnight, I were damd beyond the workes of ſuperarrogation, but to wring the whythers of my gowtie barmd ſpiggod •• igging-iumbler of elements. Mulligrub, I hold it as lawfull as ſheepe-ſhearing, taking egges from hens, caudels from Aſſes, or butterd ſhrimps from horſes, they make no vſe of them, were not prouided for them. And therefore worſhipfull Cocledemoy, hang toaſts, on, in grace and vertue to proceed, onely beware beware degrees, there be rounds in a ladder, and knots in a halter, ware carts, hang toaſts, the comon counſell has decreed it, I muſt drawe a lot for the great Goblet. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Miſtreſſe Mulligrub, and Lionell with a Goblet.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p:
Nay, I pray you ſtay and drinke, and how do's your Miſtreſſe, I know her verie well, I haue ben inward with her, and ſo has many more, ſhe was euer a good patient creature yfaith, with all my hart ile remēber your maſter an honeſt man, he knew me before I was maryed, an honeſt man hee is, and a crafty, hee comes forward in the world well, I warrant him, and his wife is a proper woman that ſhe is, well, ſhe has ben as proper a woman as any in Cheape, ſhe paints now, and yet ſhe keeps her husbands old Cuſtomers to him ſtill. Introth a fine fac'd wife, in a wainſcot carued ſeat, is a worthy ornament to a Tradeſman ſhop, and an atractiue I warrant, her husband ſhall finde it in the cuſtome of his ware, Ile aſſure him, God bee with you good youth, I acknowledge the receit. Exit Lion. I acknowledge all the rece • t ſure, tis very well ſpoken, I acknowledge the receit, thus tis to
haue good education and to bee brought vp in a Tauerne, I doe keepe as gallant and as good companie, though I ſay it, as any ſhe in London, Squiers, Gentlemen, and Knightes diet at my table, and I doe lend ſome of them money, and full many fine men goe vpon my ſcore, as ſimple as I ſtand heere, and I truſt them and truely they verie knightly and courtly promiſe faire, giue 〈◊〉 verie good words, and a peece of fleſh when time of yere ſeruet, nay, though my husband be a Citizen and's caps made of wooll, yet I ha wit, and can ſee my good aſſoone as another, for I haue all the thankes, my ſilly husband, a laſſe, hee knowes nothing of it, tis I that beare, tis I that muſt beare a braine for all.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Faire hower to you Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mu:
sp.p: Faire hower, fine terme, faith ile ſcore it vp anone a beautifull thought to you ſir.

sp.speaker: Cocl:
sp.p: Your Husband, and my Maiſter Mr. Garniſh has ſent you a Iole of freſh Salmon, and they both will come to dinner to ſeaſon your new cup with the beſt wine, which cup your husband intreats you to ſend backe by mee, that his armes may bee grau'd a the ſide, which he forgot before it was ſent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mul
sp.p: By what token, are you ſent by no token? nay, I haue wit.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: He ſent me by the ſame token, that he was dry ſhaued this morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mu.
sp.p: A fad token, but true, here ſir, I pray you commend me to your Maſter, but eſpecially to your Miſtreſſe, tell them they ſhall be moſt ſincerely welcome. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Shall be moſt ſincerely welcome, worſhipfull Cocledemoy, lurke cloſe, hang toaſts, be not aſhamed of thy qualitie, euerie mans turd ſmels well in's owne noſe, vaniſh Foyſt. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Mulligrub, with ſeruants and furniture for the Table.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mul.
sp.p:
Come ſpread theſe Table Diaper Napkins, and doe you heare, perfume this Parlour do's ſo ſmell of prophane Tabacco, I could neuer endure this vngodly Tabacco, ſince one of our Elders, aſſured me vpon his knowledge Tabacco was not vſed in the Congregation of the family of loue: ſpread, ſpread handſomely, Lord theſe boyes doe things arſie, varſie, you ſhew your bringing vp, I was a Gentlewoman by my ſiſters ſide, I can
tell yee ſo methodically: methodically, I wonder wher • it goe that word O ſir Amina dub Ruth had me kiſſe him methodically, I had it ſomewhere, and I had it indeede.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Mind, be not deſperate, ile recouer all •• thinges with me, ſhall ſeeme honeſt, that can be profitable, He muſt nere winch, that would or thriue, or ſaue, To be cal •• Nigard, cuckold, Cut-throat, Knaue.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Are they come husband?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Who? what, how n • w? what feaſt towards in my priuate Parlour.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Pray leaue your foolerie, what are they come?

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Come, who come?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: You need not mak't ſo ſtrange?

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Strange?

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: I ſtrange, you know no man that ſent me word, that he and his wife would come to dinner to me, and ſent this Iole of freſh Salmon before hand.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Peace, not I, peace, the Meſſenger hath miſtaken the houſe, let's eat it vp quickly, before it be enquir'd for ſit to it, ſom vineg • r, quicke, ſome good luck yet faith, I neuer taſted ſalmon reliſht better, oh when a man feeds at other mens coſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Other mens coſt? why did not you ſend this Iole of Salmon.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: By Maſter Garniſh man?

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Sending me word, that he and his wife would come to dinner to me.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: To ſeaſon my now bowle?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Bowle?

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: And withall wild me to ſend the bowle backe▪

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Backe?

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: That you might haue your Armes grau'd on the ſide?

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: By the ſame token you were drie ſhauen this morning before you went forth.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Pah, how this Sammon ſtinkes.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: And thereupon ſent the bowle backe, prepar'd dinner, nay and I bare not a braine.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Wife, doe not vexe, me, is the bowle gone, is it deliuer'd?

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: Deliuered! yes ſure, tis deliuered.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: I will neuer more ſay my prayers, doe not make mee madde, tis common, let me not crie like a woman, is it gone?

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: Gone? Good is my witneſſe, I deliuered it with no more intention to be cozend on't, than the child new borne: and yet

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Looke to my houſe, I am haunted with euill ſpirites, here mee, doe; heare me, if I haue not my Goblet againe, heauen, I'le to the Diuell, I'le to a Coniurer, looke to my houſe, I'le raiſe all the wiſe men ithe ſtreete.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Deliuer vs! what wordes are theſe, I truſt in God, hee is but drunke ſure.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: I muſt haue the Sammon to worſhip, Cocledemoy, now for the Maſter peece, God bleſſe thy necke peece, and Fowtra. Faire Miſtreſſe my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Haue I caught you, what Roger?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Peace good Miſtres, I'le tell you all, a leſt, a verie mere leſt, your husband onely tooke ſport to fright you, the bow • s at my Maſters, and there is your husband, who ſent me in all haſt, leaſt you ſhould be ouer frighted with his fayning, to come to dinner to him.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Praiſe Heauen, it is no worſe.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: And deſired me, to deſire you to ſend the loſe of Sammon before, and your ſelfe to come after to them, my Miſtreſſe would bee right glad to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I pray carry it: now thanke them entierly: bleſſe me, I was neuer ſo out of my skinne in my life, pray thanke your Miſtreſſe moſt entirely.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: So now Figo worſhipfull Mall • ough, and I will monch Cheaters & Bawds go together like waſhing & wringing. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: Beſhrew his heart for his labor, how euery thing about abou • me quiuers, what Chriſtian my hat and aporne, here take my ſleeues, and how I tremoſe, ſo • e goſſope it now for't, thats certaine, here has been reuolutions, and falſe hers indeed.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Whether now? Whats the matter with you now? whether are you a gadding?

sp.speaker: Meſtris.
sp.p: Come, come, play the foole no more: Will you goe?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Whether, in the ranke name of madneſſe: whether?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Whether, why to mayſter Garniſh, to eate the Iowle of Salmon? Lord, how ſtrange you make it?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Why ſo, why ſo.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Why for why did not you ſend the ſelfe ſame fellow for the Iole of Salmon, tha • had the cup?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Tis well, tis very well.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p:
And wil • me to come and eate it with you at the Gold
•••• he • .

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: OI, I, I, art in thy right w • s?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Doe you heare, make a foole of ſome body elſe, and you make an aſſe of me, I • e make an Oxe of you, do ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Nay wife be pa •• ent, for looke you, I may be madde, or drunke, or ſo, for my wiſe part, though you can bear more then I, yet I can do well: I will not cauſe nor cary, but heauen knows what I thinke. Come, lets goe neare ſome muſicke, I will neuer more ſay my praiers. Lets goe heare ſome dolefull muſicke. Nay if Heauen forget • o proſper 〈◊〉 . Ile goe no more to the Synagogue. Now I am diſcontented, Ile turne Sectarie that is faſhion.

div.head: Actus Quartus, Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Sir Hubert Subboyſe, Sir Lyonell Frevile, Criſpinella, ſeruants with lightes.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: More lights: welcome Sir Lyonell Frevile, brother Frevile ſhortly. Looke to your lights.

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.p: The Maskers are at hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Call downe our daughter: Harke they are at hande, ranke handſomly.

div.stage: Enter the Maſquers, they daunce. Enter Maheureus and take Beatrice from Frevile. They draw.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Know ſir, I haue the aduantage of the place.
You are not ſafe, I would deale euen with you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: So. They exchange gloues as pledges.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I doe beſeech you ſweet, do not for me prouoke your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: What ſodaine flaw is riſen?

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: From whence come this?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: An vlcer long time lurking, now is burſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Good ſi • the time and your deſeigns are ſoft.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I deare ſir, councell him, aduiſe him, twill relliſh well From your caruing: Good my ſweetneſt ſafe.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: As well, als well, this ſhall be ended ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: The banquet ſtaies, there weele diſcourſe more 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Marriage muſt not make m • n Cowards.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Nor rage fooles.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: "Tis valor not where hea • , but reaſon rules. Enter▪

sp.speaker: Tiſ.
sp.p: But do you heare Lady, you proud ape you. What was the leſt you brake of 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Nothing, I onely ſaide you were all mettle, that you had a brazen face, a Leaden braine, and a copperheard.

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: Quickſiluer, thou little more then a Dwarfe, and ſomething leſſe then a Woman.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: A Wiſpe, a wiſpe, a wiſpe, will you go to the banquet.

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: By the Lord I thinke thou • ilt marry ſhortly too, thou groweſt ſomewhat fooliſh already.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: O I faith, tis a faire thing to be married, and a neceſſary, To hear this word muſt, if our huſbands be proud, we muſt bear his contempt, if noyſome we muſt beare with the Gote vnder his armeholes, if a foole we muſt beare his bable, and which is worſe, If a looſe liuer, Wee muſt liue vppon vnholſome Reuerſions: Where, on the contrary ſide, our huſbands becauſe they may and we muſt; care not for vs, thinges hop'd with feare, and got with ſtruglings, are mens high pleaſures, when duety pales and flatres their appetite.

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
