sp.p: What a tart Monkey is this, by heauen if thou hadſt not ſo much wit I could finde in my hart to my marry thee. Faith bear with me for all this.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Beare with thee, I wonder how thy mother could beare th •• ten months in her bellie, when I cannot indure thee 2. hours in mine eie.

sp.speaker: Tiſ.
sp.p: Alaſſe for you ſweet ſoule, by the Lorde you are growne a proud, ſcuruie, apiſh, ydle, diſdainefull, ſcoffing, Gods foot, becauſe you haue read Ephues and his England, Palmerin de Oliva, & the Legend of Lies.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Why yfaith yet ſeruant, you of all others ſhoulde beare with my knowne vnmalicious humors, I haue alwaies in my Hart giuen you your due reſpect:
And heauen may be ſworne, I haue priuately giuen faire ſpeach of you, and proteſted.

sp.speaker: Tyſſ.
sp.p: Nay looke you, for my owne part, if I haue not as religiouſly vowd my hart to you, been in drunke to your health, ſwalowd flap-dragons, eate glaſſes, drunke vrine, ſtabd armes, and don all the offices of proteſted gallan • rie for your ſake: and yet you tell me I haue a brazen face, a leaden braine▪ and a copper bearde, Come yet and it pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: No, no, you do not loue me?

sp.speaker: Tiſ.
sp.p: By () but I do now, and whoſoeuer dares ſay that I do not loue you, nay honor you, and if you would vouchſafe to marrie.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Naie as for that thinke out as you will, but Gods my record, and my ſiſter knowes I haue taken drinke and ſlept vppont, that if euer I marrie it ſhall be you, and I will marrie, and yet I hope I do not ſaie it ſhall be you neither.

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: By heauen I ſhalbe aſſoone wearne of health as of your inioyeng: will you caſt a ſmooth cheeke vpon me?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I haue no crumpt ſhoulders, my back needs no mantle, and yet marriage is honorable: do you thinke ye ſhall proue a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Tyſſ.
sp.p: No, by the Lord, not I?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Why, I thanke you yfaith:
Heigho: I ſlept on my backe this morning
And dreamt the ſtrangeſt dreames:
Good Lord, how things will come to paſſe?
Will you go to the banquet?

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p:
If you will bee mine, you ſhall be your owne, my purſſe,
my bodie, my hart is yours, onlie bee ſilent in my houſe, modeſt at my table, and wanton in my bed, and the Empreſſe of Europe cannot content, and ſhall not be contented better.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Can anie kind hart ſpeake more diſcreetlie affectionatelie: my fathers conſent, and as for mine,

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: Then thus, and thus, ſo Hymen ſhould begin, Sometimes a falling out, proues falling in. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Frevile, speaking to ſome within, Malhereux at the other dore.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: As you reſpect my vertue, giue me leaue
To ſatisfie my reaſon, though not bloud:
So, all runs right, our fained rage hath tane
To fulleſt life, they are much poſſeſt
Of force moſt, moſt all quarrell: now my right friend
Reſolue me with open breſt, free and true hart
Cannot thy vertue hauing ſpace to thinke
and fortifie her weakened powers with reaſon,
Diſcourſes, Meditations, Diſcipline.
Diuine eiaculacories, and all thoſe aydes againſt deuils:
Cannot all theſe curbe thy lowe appetite
and ſenſuall furie?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: "There is no God in bloud, no reaſon in deſire:
Shall I but liue? Shall I not be forc't to act
Some deed, whoſe verie name is hydeous?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Then I muſt enioy Franciſchina.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: You ſhall: Ile lend this ring, ſhew it to that faire Deuill, It will reſolue me dead, which rumor with my artificiall abſence, wil make moſt firme, enioy her ſodainlie.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But if report go ſtrong that you are ſlaine, and that by me. Whereon I may be ſeizd Where ſhall I finde your being.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: At maiſter Shatewes the Iewellers, to whoſe breaſt Ile truſt our ſecret purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I reſt your ſelfe, each man hath follies.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But thoſe worſt of all,
"Who with a willing eie, do ſeeing fall.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Tis true, but truth ſeemes folly in madneſſe ſpectacles, I am not now my ſelfe, no man: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: "When womna's in the hart, in the ſoule hell.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Now repentance the fooles whip ſeize thee,
Nay if there be no meanes Ile be thy friend,
But not thy Vices; and with greateſt ſence
Ile force thee feele thy errors, to the worſt
The vildeſt of dangers thou ſhalt ſinke into,
No Ieweller ſhall ſee me, I will lurke
Where none ſhall know or thinke, cloſe Ile withdraw,
and leaue thee with two friendes: a whore and knaue
But is this vertue in me? No, not pure,
Nothing extreamely beſt with vs endures,
No vſe in ſimple purities, the elementes
are mixt for vſe, Siluer without alay
Is all to eager to be wrought for vſe:
Nor preciſe vertues euer purely good
Holdes vſefull ſize with temper of weake bloud:
Then let my courſe be borne, tho: with ſide-wind,
The end being good, the meanes are well aſsingd, Exit.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.l:
Come catafuge Fra •…
〈…〉 hall, who who he,
Excellent, Ha, heers a plmp r • mp wench, with a breaſt
Softer then a Courtyers tongue, 〈◊〉 Ladies gums,
Or an old mans mentula, my fine •• gue.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pan you poultron.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.l:
Gooddy fiſte, flump •…
〈◊〉 pum, a my fine Wagtaile,
Thou art as falſe as proſtituted and adulcerate
as ſome tranſlated manuſcript Buſſe ſayre whore, buſſe.

sp.speaker: Fra,
sp.p: Gods ſacramant. Pox.

sp.speaker: Cocle.

l.hi: Hadamoy key doſt thou frowne medianthou teukey

sp.l: Nay look heer: Numeron key Siluer blithe for cany
Os cany goblet: Ʋs key ne moy bl • gef • y 〈◊〉 pox
On you Goſling.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By me fait dis bin verie fine languge, Ick ſall buſh ye now, ha, be garzon vare had you dat place?

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Hedemoy key, get you gon Punck rampant, key common vp-taile.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: O daughter, cozen, neece, ſeruant, miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Humpum, plumpum ſquat, I am gone. Ex. Cocle.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: There is one M. Malliereux at the dore deſires to ſee you: he ſaies he muſt not be deuide, for he hath ſent you this ring and withall ſaies tis done.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Vat ſall me do now, Gods ſacramant: tell him two howers hence he ſall be moſt affectionatlie velcome, tell him (vat ſal me do) tel him Ick am bin in my bate, and Ick fall perfume my ſeetes, mak a mine bodie ſo delicate for his arme Two houres hence.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I ſhall ſatisfie him two houres hence well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Now Ick ſall reuange, hay, begar me ſal tartar de whole generation, mine braine vorke it, Frevile, is dead, Malhareux ſall hang, And mine riuall Beatrice, Ick ſall make run madde.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
Hees gone forſooth no •
〈◊〉 cawdle of Cock-ſtones, & will returne within this two houres.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Verie vel, giue mons to ſome fellow to ſquire me, Ick ſal go abroad.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Thers a luſtie Bravo beneath, a ſtranger, but a good ſtale Raſcall: he ſwea • es valiantlie, kicks a Bawd right vertuouſly, and proteſtes with an emptie pocket might deſperately, Heele ſquier you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Very velcom, mine ſan, Ick ſall re • ome preſantly, now ſal me be reuange ten touſant deula, der ſall be no got in me but paſsion, no tought but rage, no mercie but bloud, no ſpirit but Diula in me, Dere ſal noting tought good for me, But dat is miſchieuous for others. Exit

stage.hi: Enter Sir Hubert, Sir Lyonell Beatrice, Criſpin • lla, and Nurce. Tiſſefeu following.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.l: Did no one ſee him ſince? pray God, nay all is well,
A litle heat, what he is but withdrawne? and yet I would to God,
But feare you nothing.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Pray God that all be well or would I were not.

sp.speaker: Tyſſ.
sp.p: Hees not to be found Sirian • where.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: You muſt not make a heauy face preſage an ill euent: I like your Siſter well, ſhees quick and liuely: would ſhe woulde marry faith.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 , nay • ell would man a 〈…〉 an old mans a •• nentring▪

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Ha, maſſe and ſo 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: You are a Widdowe • .
Than I am I faith faire Criſp, and I can tell you, would you affect me, I haue it in me yet I faith.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Troth I am in loue, let me ſee your hand: would you ca •• your ſelfe away vpon me willingly▪

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Will I: I by the

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Woulde you be a Cockould willingly? By my troath us a comely, fine, and handſome ſight, for one of my yeeres to marry an old man, truth tis reſtoratiue what a comfortable thinge it is to thinke of her huſband to 〈◊〉 venerable cough a the euerlaſtings, no feele his rough 〈…〉 ſummer handes, and winter •• gges, his almoſte no eies, and aſſuredly no teeth, and then 〈◊〉 thinke what ſhe muſt dreame of, when ſhe conſiders others happines and her owne want: tis a worthy and notorious comfortable match.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Piſh, piſh, will you haue me▪

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Will you aſſure me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Fiue hundred pound ioynture.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: That you will die within this fortnight▪

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: No, by my faith Criſ.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Then Criſp. by her faith aſſures you ſheele haue none of you.

div.stage: Enter Frevile diſguiſ'd like apandor and Franciſchina.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p:
Beere leaue Gentles and men of night caps, I would I peak,
But that here ſtands one is able to 〈◊〉 her owne tale beſt.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
Sir mine ſpeech is to you, you 〈…〉
•• vile.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Had ha, and haue.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No po •• , me a • eome to aſſure you da • on meſt • Malheureus hath killed him.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: O me, wretched, wretched.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Looke to our daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: How art thou 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: If dat it pleaſe you to go 〈…〉 bring you •• ere you'l all hear Ma • ſhe •• eus 〈◊〉 his owne lips confeſſe it, a 〈…〉 may apprehend him and reuenge your and mine loues 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Your 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He was ſo ſir, let you 〈…〉 it do not 〈…〉 dy, de yong man dat be flame did 〈◊〉 you 〈…〉 me ten touſant touſant times more deerely.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: O my hart I will loue you the better 〈…〉 he affected? O paſsion, O my griefe which way will 〈…〉 and conſume?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Deare woes cannot ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
For looke you Ladie as your • ing he gaue 〈…〉
〈◊〉 ieſts at your ſcornd kin •
〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Bea▪
sp.p: He did not ill not to 〈…〉 did no • will as mocke me: Gentle mine 〈…〉 yet 〈…〉 Ly at not to mo • ous of ſo 〈…〉 onlie loue me was ioy enough for 〈…〉 only might onlie loue him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O but to be abuſde, ſcornde, ſcoft at, O ten touſand did • by ſuch a one, and vnto ſuch a one.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I thinke you ſaie not true • iſter, ſhall we know one another in the other world?

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: What meanes my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I would faine ſee him againe: O my torture mind, Frevile is more then dead, he is vnkinde.

div.stage: Exit Beat. and Criſp. and Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Conuey her in, and ſo ſir as you ſaid • et a ſtrong watch.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: I ſir, and ſo baſſe 〈…〉 this • a • e common woman, you muſt make it good.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ick ſall, or let me pay for his, mine bloud.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.p: Come then along all, with quiet ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: O Fate?

sp.speaker: Tyſſ.
sp.p: O ſir, be wiſely ſorrie, but not paſsionate. Exit:

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I will goe and reueale my ſelfe: ſtaie: no, no,
Greefe ende • res Loue: Heauen to haue ſuch a wife
Is happineſſe, to breed pale enuy in the ſaintes.
Thou worthy Doue-like virgin without gall,
Cannot (that womans euill) Iealouſie,
Deſpight diſgrace, nay which is worſt, contempt
Once ſtirre thy faith. O Truth, how few ſiſters haſt thou?
Deere memorie, with what a ſuffring ſweetneſſe, quiet modeſty,
Yet deepe affection ſhe receiu'd my death,
And then with what a patient, yet oppreſſed kindneſſe
She tooke my Ieudlie intimated wrongs. O the dereſt of heauen?
Were there but three ſuch women in the world, two
Might be ſaued.
Well, I am great with expectation to what deuiliſh end
This woman of foule ſoule will driue her plots:
But prouidence all wicked art ore tops.
"and Impudence muſt know (tho ſtiffe as Ice,)
"That fortune doth not alway dote on Vice. Exit.

stage.hi: Enter ſir Hubert, ſir Lyo •• ll, Tyſſeſue, Franch. and three wah Halberds.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Plant a watch there, be verie carefull Sirs, the reſt with vs.

sp.speaker: Tyſſ.
sp.p: The heauy night growes to her depth of quiet, Tis about mid darkeneſſe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mine ſhambre is hard by, Ick ſall bring you to it preſant ment.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Deepe ſilence. On

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
It was his voice, tis he: he ſuppes with his cupping glaſſes. Tis late, he muſt paſſe this waie: Ile ha him, Ile ha my fine
boy, my worſhipfull Cocledemoy, Ile moy him, he ſhall be hangd in lowſie linnen, Ile hire ſome ſectary to make him an hereticke before he die? And when he is dead Ile piſſe on his graue.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p:
Ah my fine puncks, good night, Franke, frailtie, fraile a Fraile-Hall?
• onus noches my vbiquitari.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Ware polling and ſhauing Sir.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: A Wolfe, a wolfe, a wolfe, Exit. Cocledemoy

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Heers ſomething yet, a Cloke, a cloke, yet Ile after, he cannot ſcape the watch, Ile hang him if I haue any mercy▪ Ile ſlice him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Who goes there? come before the Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Bread a God Conſtable, you are a Watch for the deuil. Honeſt men are robd vnder your noſe, thers a falſe knaue in the habit of a Vintner, ſet vpon me, he would haue had my purſe, But I tooke me to my heeles: yet he got my Cloke, a plaine ſtuffe cloke poore, yet twill ſerue to hang him? Tis my loſſe, poor man that I am.

div.stage: Enter Mulligrub running with Cocledemoys cloke.

sp.p: Maiſters, we muſt Watch better, iſt not ſtrange that knaues, Drunkerds, and theeues, ſhould be a brode, and yet we of the Watch, Scriueners, ſmithes, and Taylors, neuer ſtur.
Harke, who goes there?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: An honeſt man and a Cittiezen.
Appeare, appeare, what are you?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: A ſimple Vintner.
A Vintner ha, and ſimple, draw neerer, nerer: heers the Cloke.
I Maiſter Vintner we know you, a plaine ſtuffe cloke: tis it.
Right, come: Oh thou varlet, doeſt not thou know that the Wicked cannot ſcape the eies of the Conſtable?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: What meanes this violence, as I am an honeſt man I tooke the cloke.
As you are a knaue, you tooke the cloke, we are your witneſſes for that.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: But heare me, heare me, Ile tell you what I am.
A theefe you are.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: I tell you my name is Mullegrub.
I will grubbe you, In with him to the ſtockes, there let him ſit tell to morrow morning that Iuſtice Quodlibet may examine him.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Why but I tell thee.
Why but I tel thee, weele tell thee now.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Am I not mad, am I not an aſſe,
Why ſcabs, Gods foot: let me out.

sp.p: I, I, let him pra • e, he ſhall find matter in vs ſcabs I warrant: Gods ſo, what good members of the common wealth, doe wee proue.
Prethee peace, lets remember our duties, and let go ſleepe, in the feare of God. Excunt.

div.stage: Hauing left Mullegrub in the ſtocks.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Who goes there: I lo, ho, ho: zounds ſhall I run mad, Looſe my wits: ſhall I be hangd, hark: who goes there? Do not feare to be poore Mullegrub, Thou haſt a ſure ſtocke now.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.l: The night growes old,
And many a cockould is now Wha, ha, ha, ho,
Maids on their backes,
Dreame of ſweet ſmackes, and warme: Wo, ho, ho, ho,
I muſt go comfort my venerable Mullegrub, I muſt
Fiddle him till he fyſt: fough:
Maides in your Night-railes,
Looke well to your light
Keepe cloſe your lockes,
and downe your ſmocks,
Keepe a brode eie
And a cloſe thigh, excellent, excellent, whoſe there?
Now Lord, Lord, (maiſter Mullegrub) deliuer vs: what does your Worſhip in the ſtocks? I pray come ou • Sir.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Zounds man I tell thee I am lockt.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p:
Lockt: O world: O men: O time: o night: that canſt not
Diſcerne vertue, and wiſdome, and one of the common Counſel: What is your Worſhip in for?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: For (a plague ont) ſuſpition of Fellonie.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Nay, and it be but ſuch a trifle, Lord I could weep, to ſee your good Worſhip in this taking: your Worſhippe has beene a good friend to me, and tho you haue forgot me, yet I knewe your wife before ſhe was married, and ſince I haue found your Worſh. dore open and I haue knockt, and God knows what I haue ſaued: and doe I liue to ſee your Worſhip ſtockt?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Honeſt Belman, I perceiue thou knowſt me, I prethe call the Watch. Informe the Conſtable of my reputation, That I may no longer abide in this ſhamefull habitation, And hold thee, all I haue about me.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Tis more then I deſerue ſir: Let me alone for your Deliuerie.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Doe, and then let me alone with Cockledemoy, Ile moy him.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Maids in your: Maiſter Conſtable, whoſe that ith'ſtoks?
One for a robberie: one Mullegrub, he cals himſelfe. Mullegrub? Bel-man, knowſt thou him?

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Know him: O maiſter Conſt. what good ſeruice haue you done. Know him? Hees a ſtrong theefe, his houſe has beene ſuſpected for a bawdie Tauerne a great while: and a receipt for Cut-purſes, tis moſt certaine: He has beene long in the blacke booke, and is he tane now?
Berlady my maiſters weele not truſt the ſtocks with him, Weele haue him to the Iuſtices, get a Mittimus to Newgate preſentlie. Come ſir, come on ſir.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Ha: does your Raſcalſhip yet know my Worſhip In the end?
I, the end of your Worſhip we know.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Ha, goodman Conſtable, heeres an honeſt fellow can tell you what I am?
Tis true ſir, yare a ſtrong theefe hee ſaies on his owne knowledge: Binde faſt, binde faſt, we know you: Weele truſt no Stocks with you. Awaie with him to the Iayle inſtantlie.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Why but doſt heare Bel-man, Rogue, Raſcall, Gods
Whie but? The conſtable drags awaie mulligrub.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Whie but; wha ha ha, excellent, excellent, ha my fine Cocledemoy, my Vintner fiſtes, Ile make him fart crackers before I ha done with him; to morrow is the daie of Iudgment.
Afore the Lord God my knauerie growes vnperegall, Tis time to take a nap, vntill halfe an houre hence: God giue your Worſhip Muſicke, content, and reſt.

div.head: Actus Quintus, Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Franchiſchina, ſir Lyonel, Tiſſefeu, with Officers.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You bin verie velcom to mine ſhambra.

sp.speaker: ſir Lyo.
sp.p: But how knowe ye, how are ye aſſurde Both of the deed, and of his ſute returne.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O Myn-here. Ick ſall tell you, metre Malhereux
Came all bretleſſe running a my ſhambra
His ſword all bloudie: he tel a me he had kil Frevile,
And pred a me to conceale him:
Ick flatter him, bid bring monies, he ſhould liue and lie vid me,
He went whilſt Ick (me hope vidout ſins) out of mine
Muſh loue to Frevile betraie him.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Feare not, tis well: good works get grace for ſin.
sp.stage: She conceales them behinde the curtaine.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Dere, peace, reſt dere, ſo ſoftlie, all goe in:
De net is laie, now ſal Ick be reuenge.
If dat me knew a dog dat Frevile loue,
Me would puiſſon him, for know de deepeſt hell
As a reuenging Womans, naught ſo fell.

sp.speaker: mary.
sp.p: Ho Coſen Francke, the partie you wot of, M. Malhereux.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Bid him come vp, I prede.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O min here man, a dere liuer Loue,
Mine ten touſant times velcom Loue,
Ha, by mine trat, you bin de iuſt, vat ſall me ſaie:
Vat ſeet honie name ſall I call you?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Anie from you is pleaſure. Come my louing
Prettineſſe, wheres thie Chamber?
I long to touch your ſheetes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, no, not yet mine ſeeteſt ſoft-lipped loue:
You ſall not gulp downe all delights at once:
Be min trat, dis all-fles-Louers, dis rauenous Wenches
Dat ſallow all downe hole, vill haue all at one bit,
Fie, fie, fie, be min fait dey do eate
Comfets vid ſpoones.
No, no, Ile make you chew your pleaſure vit loue,
"De more degrees and ſteps, de more delight,
"De more endeered is de pleaſure hight.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What your a lerned wanton, and proceed by art?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Go little vag, pleaſure ſhould haue a
Cranes long necke, to reliſh de Ambroſia of
Delight.
And Ick pre de tel me, for me loues to heare of manhood
Verie muſh, Iſait: Ick prede (vat vas me a ſaieng)
Oh, Ick prede tell a me:
How did you kill a metre Frevile?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why quareld a ſet purpoſe, drew him out, Singled him, and hauing th'advantage of my ſword and might, ran him through and through.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Vat did you vid him van he was ſticken?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I dragd him by the heeles to the next wharffe and ſpurnd him in the Riuer.

div.stage: Thoſe in ambuſh ruſheth forth and takes him.

sp.speaker: ſir Lyo.
sp.p: Seize, ſeize him: O monſterous? O ruthleſſe Villaine?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: What meane you Gentlemen? by heauen,

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: Speake not of anie thing thats good.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Your errors giues you paſsion: Frevile liues.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Thie own lips ſaie, thou lieſt.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Let me die if at Shatewes the Ieweller, he liues not ſafe vntoucht.

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: Meane time to ſtrickteſt guard, to ſharpeſt priſon.

sp.speaker: Mall
sp.l: No rudeneſſe Gentlemen: Ile go vndragd.
O wicked, wicked Diuell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.l: Sir, the daie of triall is this morn,
Lets proſecute the ſharpeſt rigor, and ſeuereſt end:
"Good men are cruell, when the'are vices friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.l: Woman we thanke thee, with no emptie hand,
Strumpets are fit, fit for ſom-thing. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I, for Hell: O thou vnrepriueable, beyond all
Meaſure of Grace dambd immediatlie:
That things of beautie created for ſweet vſe:
Soft comfort, and as the verie muſicke of life,
Cuſtome ſhould make ſo vnutterablie helliſh?
O heauen, what difference is in women, and their life?
What man, but worthie name of Man:
Would leaue the modeſt pleaſures of a lawfull bed:
The holie vnion of two equall harts
Mutuallie holding either deere as health,
The vndoubted yſſues, Ioyes of chaſt ſheetes,
The vnfained imbrace of ſober Ignorance:
To twine the vnhealthfull loynes of common Loues,
The proſtituted impudence of things.
Senceleſſe like thoſe by Cataracks of Nyle,
"Their vſe ſo vile, takes awaie ſence how vile,
"To loue a creature, made of bloud and hell,
"Whoſe vſe makes weake, whoſe companie doth ſhame,
"Whoſe bed doth begger: yſſue doth defame.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Metre Frevile liue: ha, ha, liue at meſtre Shatewes:
Muſh at metre Shatews. Frevile is dead. Malhereux ſall hang,
And ſwete diuel, dat Beatrice would but run mad, dat
ſhe would but run mad, den me would dance and ſing,
Metre Don Dubon, me pre ye now go to Meſtres
Beatrice, tel her Frevile is ſure ded, and dat he
Curſſe hir ſelfe eſpeciallie, for dat he was
Sticked in hir quarrell, ſwering in his laſt gaſpe,
Dat if it had bin in mine quarrels,
Twould neuer haue greeued him.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Prede do, and ſaie anie ting dat vil vex her.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Let me alone to vex her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Vil you, vil you mak a her run mad? here take
Dis ring, ſea me ſcorne to wear anie ting dat washers,
Or his: I prede torment her, Ick cannot loue her,
She honeſt and vertuous forſooth.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Is ſhe ſo? O vile creature? then let me alone with her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Vat. Vil you mak a her mad? ſeet by min trat,
Be pretta ſeruan, Buſh, Ick ſall go to bet now.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Miſchiefe whether wilt thou? O thou tear-leſſe woman?
How monſtrous is thy Deuill,
The end of Hell as thee.
How miſerable were it to be vertuous, if thou couldſt proſper?
Ile to my Loue, the faithfull Beatrice,
She has wept enough, and faith deere ſoule too much.
But yet how ſweet it is to thinke
How deere ones life was to his Loue: how moornd his death.
Tis Ioy not to be expreſt with breath:
But O let him that would ſuch paſsion drinke,
Be quiet of his ſpeech, and onlie thinke. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Siſter, cannot a woman kill her ſelfe? Is it not lawfull to die when we ſhould not liue?

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: O ſiſter tis a queſtion not for vs, we muſt do what God will.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What God will? Alaſſe, can torment be his glorie, or our greefe his pleaſure? Does not the Nurces nipple iuic'd ouer with Wormwood, bid the childe it ſhoulde not ſucke? And does not Heauen when it hath made our breath bitter vnto vs, ſay we ſhud not liue? O my beſt ſiſter: to ſuffer wounds when one may ſcape this rod, is againſt nature, that is againſt God.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Good ſiſter do not make me weep: ſure Frevile was not falſe: Ile gage my life that ſtrumpet out of craft
And ſome cloſe ſecond end hath maliſt him.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: O ſiſter if he were not falſe, whom haue I loſt?
If he were: what griefe to ſuch vnkindneſſe,
From head to foote I am all myſerie:
Onely in this, ſome iuſtice I haue found
My griefe is like my loue, beyond all bound. Enter Nurſe

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: My ſeruant, maiſter Cacature deſires to viſite you,

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.l: For griefes ſake keepe him out, his diſcourſe is like the long word, Honorificabilitudinitatibus: a great deale
Of ſound and no ſence: his companie is like a parentheſis.
To a diſcourſe you may admit it, or leau it out, it makes no matter.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: By your leau • ſweet creatures.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Sir, all I can yet ſay of you, is, you are vnciuill.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You muſt denie it: By your ſorrowes leaue,
I bring ſome muſſicke, to make ſweet your griefe,

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: What ere you pleaſe: O breake my hart
Canſt thou yet pant? O doſt thou yet ſeruiue,
Thou didſt not loue him, if thou now canſt liue▪

div.l: O Loue, how ſtrangely ſweet
are thy weake Paſſions,
That loue and ioy 〈…〉
in ſelfe ſame faſhions.
O who can tell
the cauſe why this ſhould moue▪
But onely this,
no reaſon, aſke of L •• e.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p:
Hold, peace, the ge •
〈…〉 O my beſt ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Ha, get you gone, cloſe the dores: My Beatrice,
Curſt be my indiſcreet trials: O my immeaſureablie louing.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: She ſtirs, giue aire, ſhe breathes.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Where am I, ha? how haue I ſlipt off life?
Am I in heauen? O my Lord, though not louing
By our eternall being, yet giue me leaue
To reſt by thie dear ſide: am I not in heauen?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: O eternallie much laued, recollect your ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Ha, you do ſpeake, I do ſee you, I do liue,
I would not die now: Let me not burſt with wonder.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Call vp your bloode, I liue to honor you,
As the admired glorie of your ſex.
Nor euer hath my loue bin falſe to you.
Onely I preſum'd to try your faith too much,
For which I moſt am grieued.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Brother; I muſt be plaine with you, you haue wrong'd vs.
I am not ſo Couetous to deny it,
But yet when my diſcourſe hath ſtaide your quaking,
You will be ſmoother lipt: and the delight
And ſatisfaction which we all haue got,
Vnder theſe ſtrange diſguiſings, when you know,
You will be milde and quiet, forget at laſt,
"It is much ioy to thinke on ſorrowes paſt.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Do you then liue? and are you not • ntrue?
Let me not die with Ioy, pleaſure's more extream:
Then greefe, thers nothing ſweet to ma • but meane.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Heauen cannot be too gratious to ſuch goodneſſe, I ſhall diſcourſe to you the ſeueral chances, but harke I muſt yet reſt diſguiſd, the ſudden cloſe of many drifts now meet,
"Where pleaſure hath ſome profit, ar • is ſweet. Enter Tiſefeu.

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: Newes, newes, newes, newes.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Oyſters, Oyſters, oyſters, oyſters.

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: Why, is not this well now? Is not this better then louring, and pouting, and puling, which is hatefull to the liuing, and vaine to the dead? Come, come, you muſt liue by the quicke, when all is done, and for my owne part, let my wife laugh at me when I am dead, ſo ſ • eele ſmile vpon me whilſt I liue, but to ſee a woman Whine, and yet keepe her eies 〈◊〉 mourne, and yet keepe her cheekes fat: nay, to ſee a woman c • aw her huſbande by the feete when he is dead, that would haue ſcratcht him by the face whe • he was liuing: this now is ſomewhat rediculous.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Lord how you prate.

sp.speaker: Tiſ.
sp.p: And yet I was afraide ifaith that I ſhoulde ha ſeene a Garland on this beauties herſe, but time, truth, experience, and varietie, are great doers with women.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: But whats the newes? the newes I pray you?

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: I pray you? nere pray me: for by your leaue you may command me. This tis: the publique ſeſsions which this day is paſt, hath doom'd to death ill fortun'd Malhereux.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: But ſir, we heard he offerd to make good,
That Freuile liu'd at Shatews the Iewellers.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: And that twas but a plot betwixt them two.

sp.speaker: Tyſſ.
sp.l: O I, I, he gagd his life with it, but know
When all approcht the teſt, Shatews deuide
He ſaw or heard of any ſuch complot,
Or of Freuill: ſo that his owne defence,
Appeard ſo falſe, that like a madmans ſword,
He ſtroke his owne hart, he hath the courſe of law
and inſtantly muſt ſuffer: but the Ieſt
(If hanging be a ieſt) as many make it)
Is to take notice of one Mullegrub, a ſharking vintner.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: What of him Sir.

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: Nothing but hanging, the Whoreſone ſlaue is mad before he hath loſt his ſences.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Was his fact cleere and made aparant Sir?

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.l: No faith ſuſpitions, for twas thus proteſted
a cloke was ſtolne, that cloke he had, he had it
Himſelfe confeſt by force, the reſt of his defence
The choller of a Iuſtice wrongd in wine,
Ioynd with malignance of ſome haſtie Iurors,
Whoſe wit was lighted by the Iuſtice noſe, The knaue was caſt,
But Lord to heare his mone, his praiers, his wiſhes,
His zeal ill timde, and his words vnpittied,
Would make a dead man riſe and ſmile,
Whilſt he obſerued how feare can make men vile.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Shall we go meet the execution?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I ſhall be rulde by you.

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.l: By my tro • h a rare motion, you muſt haſt,
For male-factors goes like the world vpon wheeles.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Will you man vs, you ſhall be our guide to Freuile.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I am your ſeruant.

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: Ha ſeruant? Zounds I am no companion for Pandors▪ your beſt make him your loue.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: So will I Sir, we muſt liue by the quicke you ſay.

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.l: Sdeath a vertue, what a damnd things this?
Whole truſt faire faces, teares, and vowes, Sdeath not I,
She is a woman, that is, ſhe can ly.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Come, come, turne not a man of time, to make al il,
Whoſe goodneſſe you conceiue 〈◊〉 , ſince the • orſt of chance

Is to craue grace for 〈…〉
▪

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: So, I ha loſt my Sergeant in an ecliptique miſt, drunke, horrible drunke, he is fine: ſo now will I fit my ſelfe, I hope this habit will do me no harme, I am an honeſt man already: fit, fit, fit as a puncks taile, that ſerues euery body: By this time my Vintner thinkes of nothing but hel and ſulpher, he farts fire and brimſtone already, hang toſtes, the execution approcheth.

div.stage: Enter Sir Lyonell: Sir Hubert, Malhereux piniond, Tyſefeu, Beatrice, Frevile, Criſp. Franciſchina, and Holberds.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I do not bluſh, although condemnd by lawes,
No kind of death is ſhamefull but the cauſe:
Which I do know is none, and yet my luſt
Hath made the one (although not cauſe) moſt iuſt.
May I not be repriued? Freuile is but miſlodgd,
Some lethargie hath ſeazd him, no, much mallice,
Do not lay bloud vpon your ſoules with good inten •• ,
Men may do ill and law ſometime repents.

div.stage: Cockledemoy picks Malhereuxes pocket of his purſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Sir, ſir, prepare, vaine is all lewd defence.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: "Conſcience was law: but now lawes Conſcience,
My endles peace is made, and to the poore,
My purſe, my purſe.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: I Sir, and it ſhall pleaſe you the poore has your purſe a • .

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You are a Welyman,
But now thou ſourſe of Deuils, Oh how I lothe
The very memory of that I adorde,
He thats of faire bloud, well meand, of good breeding,
Beſt fam'd, of ſweet acquaintance and true friends▪
And would with deſperate Impudence looſe all theſe,
And hazard landing at this fatall ſhore,
Ler him nere kill, nor ſteale, but loue a Whore,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
De man doſe raue, tinck a got, tinck a got, and bid d •••
• leſh, de world, and the dible farewell.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Farewell. Freuile diſcouers himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Vat iſt you ſea, ha?

sp.speaker: Fre▪
sp.l: Sir your pardon, with my this defence,
Do not forget proteſted violence
Of your low affections no requeſts,
No arguments of reaſon, no knowne dan • er.
No aſſured wicked bloodines,
Could draw your hart from this damnation.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why ſtaie.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Vnproſperous Diuell, vat ſall me do now.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Therefore to force you from the truer danger,
I wrought the fained, ſuffering this faire Deuil,
In ſhaps of woman to make good her plot,
And knowing that the hooke was deeply faſt,
I gaue her line at will, till with her owne vaine ſtriuings,
See here ſhees tired: O thou comely damnation?
Doeſt think that vice is not to be withſtood,
O what is woman meerely made of bloud.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: You maze vs all, let vs not be loſt in darkeneſſe?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: All ſhall be lighted, but this time and place
Forbids longer ſpeech, onlie what you can thinke
Has bin extreamlie ill is onelie hers.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: To ſeuereſt priſon with her, with what hart canſt liue? What eies behold a face?

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.l: Ick vil not ſpeake, torture, torture your fill,
For me am worſe then hangd, me ha loſt my will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: To the extreameſt whip and Iaile.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Frolique, how is it Sirs?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I am my ſelfe, how long waſt ere I could
Perſwade my paſsion to grow calme to you?
Rich ſence makes good bad language, and a friend
Should waigh no action, but the actions end.
I am now worthie yours, when before
The beaſt of man, looſe bloud diſtemperd vs,
"He that luſt rules cannot be vertuous.

div.stage: Enter Mullegrub miſtris Mullegrub and officers.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: On afore there, roome for the priſoners?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: I praie you do not lead me to execution through cheapeſide, I owe M. Burniſh the gold-ſmith monie, and I feare heele ſet a Seriant on my backe for it.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Trouble not your skonce my Chriſtian Brothers, but haue an eie vnto the maine chance, I will warrant your ſhouldiers, as for your necke Plinius ſecundus, or marcus Tullius Cycero, or ſomebodie it is ſaies, that a three foulde corde is hardlie broken.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Wel, I am not the firſt honeſt man that hath bin caſt away, and I hope ſhall not be the laſt.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: O ſir, haue a good ſtomach and mawes, you ſhal haue a ioyfull ſupper.

sp.speaker: Muly.
sp.p: In troth I haue no ſtomach to it, and it pleaſe you take my trencher▪ I vſe to faſt at nights.

sp.speaker: miſtris mul.
sp.p: O husband, I little thought you ſhould haue come to think on God thus ſoon: nay and you had bin hangd deſeruedly, it would neuer haue greeud me, I haue known of many honeſt innocent men haue bin hangd deſeruedly, but to be caſt away for nothing.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Good woman hold your peace, your prittles & your prattles your bibbles and your babbles, for I pray you heare mee in priuate, I am a widdower, and you are almoſt a widdow, ſhal I be welcom to your houſes, to your tables, and your other things.

sp.speaker: miſt mul.
sp.p: I haue a peece of mutton and a featherbed for you at all times, I pray make haſt.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: I do here make my confeſsion, if I owe anie man anie thing, I do hartilie forgiue him: if any man owe me anie thing, let him paie my wife.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: I will looke to your wi • es paiment I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: And now good yoke-fellow leaue thy poor mulligrub.

sp.speaker: miſt. mul.
sp.p: Naie then I were vnkind yſaith, I will not leaue you vntill I haue ſeene you hang.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p:
But brothers, brothers, you muſt thinke of your ſins and iniquities, you haue bin a brocher of prophane veſſels, you haue made vs drinke of the iuice of the whore of Babylon, for whereas good ale, Perrys, Bragets, Syders, and metheglins, was the true auntient Britiſh and Troyan drinks, you ha brought in Popiſh wines, Spaniſh wines, French wines, tam marti quam mercurio, both muſcadi ••
and malmſey, to the ſubuerſion, ſtaggering, and ſometimes ouerthrow of manie a good Chriſtian: You ha bin a great Iumbler, O remember the ſins of your nights, for your night works ha bin vnſauorie in the taſt of your Cuſtomers.

sp.speaker: mul.
sp.p: I confeſſe, I confeſſe, and I forgiue as I would be forgiuē, Do you know one Cocledemoy?

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: O verie wel: know him? an honeſt man he is and a comly, an vpright dealer with his neighbours, and their wiues ſpeake good things of him.

sp.speaker: mul.
sp.p: Wel, wherſoere he is, or whatſoere he is, Ile take it on my death hees the cauſe of my hanging, I hartily forgiue him, and if he would come forth he might ſaue me, for he only knowes the why, and the wherfore.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: You do from your harts, and midrifs, and intrales forgiue him then you wil not let him rot in ruſty Irons, procure him to be hangd in lowſie linnen without a ſong, and after he is dead piſſe on his graue.

sp.speaker: mul.
sp.p: That hard hart of mine has procurd all this, but I forgiue as I would be forgiuen.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hang toſts my Worſh.

sp.speaker: mulli.
sp.p: behold thy Cocledemoy, my fine vintner, my caſtrophomicall fine boy: behold and ſee.

sp.speaker: Tyſſ.
sp.p: Bliſſe, a the bleſſed, who would but look for 2. knaues here?

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p:
No knaue worſh. friend, no knaue, for obſerue honeſt C ••
cledemoy reſtores whatſoeuer he has got, to make you know, that whatſoere he has don, has bin only Euphoniae gratia, for Wits ſake: I acquit this Vintner as he has acquitted me, all has bin done for Emphiſes of wit my fine boie, my worſhipfull friends.

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: Goe you are a flattring knaue.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: I am ſo, tis a good thriuing trade, it coms forward better then the 7. liberal Sciences, or the nine cardinall vertues, whiche may well appeare in this, you ſhall neuer haue flattering knaue turn courtyer: and yet I haue read of many Courtyers that haue turned flattring knaues.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Waſt euen but ſo, why then als well?

sp.speaker: mull.
sp.p: I could euen weepe for ioy.

sp.speaker: miſt, mul.
sp.p: I could weep to, but God knowes for what.

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: Hers another tack to be giuen, your ſon and daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Iſt poſsible, hart I, al my hart, wil you be ioyned here?

sp.speaker: Tyſ.
sp.p: yes • aith father, mariage and hanging are ſpun both in one houre.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p:
Why then my worſh. good friends I bid my ſelfe moſt hartily welcome to your merry nuptials, and wanton Iigga-ioggies And now my verie fine Heliconian Gallantes, and you my Worſh. friends in the middle Region:
If with content our hurtleſſe mirth hath bin,
Let your pleaſd minds as our much care hath bin:
For he ſhall find that ſlights ſuch triuiall wit,
Tis eaſier to reproue then better it:
We ſcorne to feare, and yet we feare to ſwell,
We do not hope tis beſt: tis all, 〈…〉
Exe •
